In sharp contrast to the University of Queensland taking half of their intake from south of the border, James Cook University will make 20 places for people from regional centres, from the small towns, because they know there is a far greater chance of those people going back to the small towns if in fact they come from the small towns; and for this we must thank them very sincerely.

I also wanted to thank today Mary Jane Streeton who, in her job with the Premier's Department as the Premier's representative in North Queensland, was tireless in her energies and almost obsessive in her pursuit of this objective. She has worked subsequently at the university with Dr John Stokes. I want to thank Dr John Stokes and his curriculum teamâI single out Maggie Grant-Wronski and I will say a bit more about her husband in a moment or twoâfor the excellent work that they have done and the approach they have taken. I also thank Bob Porter, the planning dean from Monash Universityâa gift from the gods for us. I must single out Bernard Moulden, who took Ken McKinnon's place, which were very big shoes to fill. It was very hard for him to come in after a person such as Ken, but we would simply not have got this medical school without Bernard's compassion, intelligence and determination.

Finally, I come back to Ian Wronskiâhe has spent probably two decades in Broome and such other regional centresâwith his passionate commitment, unbounded energy and unquenchable enthusiasm. This project was dead at least 12 times, and every single time his unbounded enthusiasm took us back to the coalface once again. Every time I think of Ian Wronski, I cannot help but think of the last scene in the famous Christopher Columbus movie with Gerard Depardieu in it where Christopher Columbus is talking to the Director of the Madrid Academy of Scienceâthe most distinguished institute of learning in the entire civilised world. In that scene the Director of the Madrid Academy said, `Christopher Columbus, no-one will ever remember your name. We have decided that Americas founded America. It will be called America, and you will be forgotten,' and he looked very pleased with himself. Christopher Columbus looked out on the city of Madrid and said, `Look out there, what do you see?' The director of the academy said, `I see civilisation. I see learning. I see beautiful buildings. I see every achievement that man can put together.' Christopher Columbus then said, `Men like me built this city. Men like you had nothing to do with the building of this city.' I cannot help but think of that final scene when I think about Ian Wronski. We owe him a very great debt of gratitude.

talk.start.para: âIn keeping with the seemingly inexorable drive towards a republic, it is timely that we as parliamentarians reflect on the great philosopher of old, Plato, who wrote The Republic some 300 years before Christ. The Reverend Peter Hastie, a Presbyterian pastor in Ashfield, Sydney, has kindly provided me with a copy of Mr Barney Zwartz's article in the Australian Presbyterian titled `The PM Paradox'. The article notes:

speech.para: Plato would be appalled at the idea that we should encourage those driven by desire for reward or power to rule us, for these are precisely the people who are least qualified.

Mr Zwartz also says, `The idea that if you paid the Prime Minister five times as much, you get five times the quality of government is laughable.' The utilitarian ethic grips Australia like a vice. It is a vice! It offends Plato's early recognition that self-interest does not generate the best decisions. Self-interest does not, cannot and never will do this. Utilitarianism is a false ideology.

Parliamentarians must be motivated by ethics higher than utilitarianism, which is in direct opposition to the natural law, the rule of law and codes of ethics which must be the foundation of any republic. We must oppose utilitarianism for the imposter that it is. Zwartz notes:
The secular Australia of 1998 may not esteem devotion to God but we all prize the other items on the list . . . e.g. the central Christian ethical priority of setting others above ourselves.
Utilitarianism is the antithesis of our cultural heritage. We must strive towards Plato's academy and make for a society governed by philosopher kings.

talk.start.para: âAnd the monarchy.

âI thank Reverend Peter Hastie for bringing Mr Zwartz's article to my attention and thus providing me with this brief opportunity to bring this message to the notice of members of this House. Unlike the minister at the table, the Minister for Employment Services, I look forward, like the majority of members in this House, to a republic. I hope that on 6 November Australians say what they really believeâthat they want one of us, an Australian, to be our head of state.
âIt being 8 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: The following notices were given:
Mr Hockey to present a bill for an act to amend the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Act 1999, and for other purposes.
Mr Hockey to present a bill for an act relating to the conduct of, and the disclosure of information by, life companies, life brokers and life insurance advisers, and for related purposes.
Mr Horne to move:
That the House:
(1) acknowledges the oyster industry as a responsible industry that is a large employer of people both directly and indirectly in regional Australia;

(2) recognises that regional jobs are rapidly diminishing and the loss of a viable oyster industry would result in the loss of thousands of jobs in coastal Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria; and

(3) calls on the Government as a matter of urgency to exclude oyster farmers from having to value their oyster crop as an asset and therefore be considered as income for taxation purposes starting in the year 2000-2001.
Mr Albanese to move:
That this House:
(1) supports the United Nations Organisation of African Unity Referendum for the Western Sahara;

(2) applauds the efforts of the UN Secretary General Kofi Annan and his special envoy for Western Sahara Mr James Baker to ensure that a free and fair Referendum is held in Western Sahara to allow its people to exercise their right to self-determination; and
(3) calls on the Government to reintroduce its contingent to the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO).
Mr Hollis to move:
That this House:
(1) calls on the Government to reverse the decision on the transmitters at Cox Peninsula near Darwin; and
(2) urges the Government to recommence broadcasting from Cox Peninsula as a matter of urgency.

talk.start.para: âtook the chair at 9.40 a.m.

âThe Victorian state election held on Saturday in my view was not a referendum on Jeff Kennett, though he tried to make it such. It was an election about competing policies for Victoria and for communities. Many people treated the poll as a referendum on local services and what the Kennett government had done in their area and planned to do in the future.

speech.para: In my local area the referendum was about the future of the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre. The Kennett government had decided to sell this fantastic hospital, the largest teaching hospital in Victoria. The Austin is also one of the leading medical research hospitals in Australia, with the Austin Medical Research Institute being at the forefront of research into cancer and other life threatening illnesses. It is also important, with yesterday having been Alzheimer's Day, to acknowledge the research done at the Memory Loss Clinic at the Austin and, in particular, the clinical trials performed on Aricept, a drug that many in the field see as groundbreaking in the treatment of memory loss. There are many other very important areas of research that the Austin undertakes but, given the time, I have not got the capacity to go through those today.

The two state electorates where the Austin and Repat sits recorded large swings to Labor at the recent election. In Ivanhoe, the swing was one of the largest in the metropolitan area, at over 4.4 per cent, and in Bundoora it was around 3.3 per cent. Ivanhoe is a seat that has been held by the Labor Party for only six years since 1955. We can be sure that the Liberals have lost the referendum on the sale of our hospital.

During the election campaign we had the now departing Minister for Health, Rob Knowlesâhe lost his seat with a 9.6 per cent swingâvisiting volunteers at the hospital to attempt to assure them of the future of services at the site and the ongoing importance of their role. To say that the reception he got was frosty is a vast understatement. They made it clear that volunteering to work for a for-profit company was very different from working for a publicly owned and operated hospital. They rightly felt betrayed by the Kennett government. I hope now that we have won the fight to save the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre.

I know that the Labor Party has listened and is committed to public hospitals. If we do end up with a Labor government, we will have a strengthened, publicly owned Austin and Repat. If the Liberals do scrape back, they must end this ideological obsession with the first sale of a major teaching hospital in Australia. The local community deserve to be heard. They do not want their hospital sold.

talk.start.para: âToday I want to acknowledge the achievements of the 1999 Voices of Youth National Roundtable participants. The 50 young people, aged 15 to 24, who comprise this task force have shown themselves to be eminently capable of communicating the priorities and expectations of the young Australians they were selected to represent to government some 12 months ago.

speech.para: Few of these young people had prior experience in managing the kinds of demands that they have been challenged with and the issues they have been challenged to confront. They are a credit to themselves, their families, their schools and their local communities, and I have found them truly inspirational.

At the time the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs announced the establishment of the youth roundtable there were a small band of critics, largely from the opposition, who said that they would never be taken seriously, that they would be inadequately funded, and that they were not broadly representative. Having spent many hours with these young people, I can say that these critics were very wrong. I am full of praise for the work that has come forward from the participants in the youth roundtable.

At the March meeting of the youth roundtable, members prepared a draft preamble to the Constitution, which was formally presented to cabinet. I understand that they had some success, with some of the words that were put forward bearing fruition as to what other Australians will now be voting for on 6 November. The environment group submitted a paper to Senator Hill's environmental education discussion paper entitled Today shapes tomorrow.

The roundtable participants have also had an effect upon my own work. The health and wellbeing group, which is self-selected, has assisted me greatly as I have looked at issues confronting drug use and misuse among school children and what can be done about educating them. They have shown themselves to be big picture thinkers who have given careful consideration to all their own ideas. The team was united in their belief that, irrespective of how `in your face' or how graphic drug education is, some young people will continue to glorify drug use until they are made aware of the horrors involved and how personally destructive drug misuse and abuse is. This is a very important observation, and I have made sure that this message has been communicated to the media and health and education professionals.

The ability of roundtable participants to inspire the confidence of others is reflected in their selection to serve on a wide range of national, state and local committees. I am pleased to have personally endorsed the selection of Mr Simon Baptist to the UNESCO national education group committee, and I have made another recommendation for a special task force membership which is yet to be announced. I also recognise the efforts of Ashley Couzens in consulting with Aboriginal elders and indigenous young people in his own community. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to praise the role of Australian troops in East Timor and, in particular, to draw the attention of the Australian public to the role of Major General Cosgrove in going to Dili before his own troops did. That act of courage is something that should not be underestimated and, in my view, it has played a key role in allowing Australian troops, and UNAMET forces generally, to ease their way in there relatively peacefully. I have only limited military experienceâtwo years in the officers school in the Army Reserve in the early 1980sâbut a couple of months ago I had the privilege of visiting, with the Labor spokesman on defence, Mr Steve Martin, the 3rd Brigade in Townsville. From my own limited military experience, I could see that those troops in the 3rd Brigade, some of whom have already been deployed in Dili and other places, are extremely capable. I believe that, together with Major General Cosgrove, they will acquit themselves in the fine military tradition of Australia.

speech.para: I want to turn to two aspects of this Timor affair that particularly concern me. One relates to a program that will appear on the ABC on Thursday night. This shows the interception of secrets during the Second World War by GCHQ Cheltenham and the effort that the British had to go to during the Second World War to intercept German Enigma messages and the war-winning secret known as Ultra. Australia, its allies and people in Asia do not have the problem of intercepting messages about what has happened in East Timor. We know what has happened, according to newspaper reports, because of the open communications that took place between elements of the Indonesian military and some of their militia thugs in East Timor.

I believe that subsequently, further down the line, it is very important that the United Nations and Australia push for an international war crimes tribunal so that the people whose role is known will be tracked down and will attract the appropriate international opprobrium. This is very important for the people of Indonesia, as well as for Australia. It is very important that Australians make clear that we are frustrated with the Indonesian militaryânot with the Indonesian people. If Indonesian democracy is to flower, we will have to make sure that the role of the people who perpetrated those deeds in East Timor is well known.

The other matter that I will come to at a later stage during the Timor debate is my belief that Australia-US congressional liaison and our diplomacy in the United States need a great deal of improvement. I think that explains, perhaps, the American lack of appreciation of our role. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to make some remarks about the tragedy that has occurred in Taiwan in the last few hours and extend my sympathy and support to the people of that courageous island. Recently a democracy, Taiwan is making great economic gains and showing the way to Asia in so many areas. It has tremendous strategic reserves and a self-reliant people offers an example that matches anything which the nation of Japan has achieved.

speech.para: The tragedy that has occurred there is an earthquake of, I am told, 7.6 on the Richter scale, equivalent to the earthquake that caused the tragedy in Turkey, but in a very highly populated community. According to Australian sources from the minister's office, there are 1,546 people confirmed dead, 3,841 injured and 2,304 unaccounted for. Whilst the epicentre was not in Taipei, it was close by. Buildings and dwellings are shattered, many people are out on the streets, afraid to go back in their dwellings. The Japanese and the Americans have offered full support. I notice the government of China has also offered support. The estimates on the homeless numbers are that about 100,000 people are homeless at this stage.

Australia has strong links with Taiwan and many people from Taiwan have settled in Australia over a long period of time. They have a long and historic settlement program in Australia. I have found them to be outstanding citizens. No doubt their concerns for family members and friends would be pre-eminent in their minds at this moment. I would like to convey to Po-Lun Liu, Representative, and to Maggie Tien, Director-General, the unofficial representatives in Australia, the warm regards and the sympathy and condolences of myself and of the Australian parliament, if I may take that on myself, Mr Deputy Speaker, and maybe it is something you might wish to pursue later.

The people of Taiwan are amazingly productive. From a resource scarce island, they have produced amazing results. So at this time I trust that Australia, stretched as we are, can do more than express our sympathy. In any small way at this time, a nation in our sphere of influence should be encouraged and it should understand that family members in our region feel for the families that have suffered loss or destruction of property.

subdebateinfo.title: New South Wales: Local Government Elections

talk.start.para: âOther members have dealt with global matters. I would like to bring to the Main Committee's attention an intensely local matterâthe success of the Labor Party teams for the Campbelltown and Liverpool local government elections in my electorate on 11 September. The Labor team in Campbelltown increased its numbers from three to five in a resounding result. I particularly congratulate the two new Campbelltown councillors, Aaron Rule and Stephen Chaytor. I am sure in coming yearsâ

speech.para: Mr Sercombe interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am involved in all campaigns in Campbelltown, Bob, and they are all successful. I congratulate Councillors Rule and Chaytor on their election. They are bound to play a very important role in coming years in the modernisation of Campbelltown City Council. But the most stunning result was at Liverpool, where the ALP increased its numbers to seven out of a total of 11 councillors. This is a stunning result, particularly in the increased majority for Mayor George Paciullo. It puts to bed two myths about politics in Western Sydney. The first of those is that the proposed development of Badgerys Creek airport is electorally unpopular.

speech.para: Liverpool council is the only council in Western Sydney that publicly supports the development of the second airport. Mayor Paciullo has been leading that campaign for a number of years. His result is proof positive that Badgerys Creek is a positive development, particularly given its employment impact. He increased his majority, recording a resounding 58 per cent of the vote. His main anti-airport opponent, Councillor Colin Harrington, received just 16 per cent of the vote. So the people of Liverpool have given a very clear indication, putting to bed one of the myths about our politics in Western Sydneyâthe idea that the airport might be electorally unpopular.

But look also at the results in the South Ward, where there was a candidate called Joane Vella, who also ran against the airport development. I am told that Joane Vella is the sister of the hysterical and unlovely Kay Vella, who has been leading the campaign against Badgerys Creek in Western Sydney. Joane Vella in the South Ward of Liverpool council received just 259 votes, a result that somewhat matches Kay Vella's poor performance when she stood for the Lindsay by-election in 1996. The Vellas are out. Paciullo and an increased Labor majority standing for the airport development are in. That is a very clear sign for the federal government, dispensing with some of these myths about the politics of Badgerys Creek.

The second myth put to bed is the idea that vested interests can influence votes. In fact, the misguided campaign by the existing licensed clubs in Liverpool to stop the development of a competitor club at Woodward Park was also a dismal failure. Their donations to Colin Harrington were a waste of members' funds and, as I pointed out earlier, Harrington went backwards, receiving just 16 per cent of the vote. This is a triumph for Labor in south-west Sydney and, as the member for Maribyrnong pointed out, I am very pleased to have been associated with it. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Recognition Awards for Senior Australians

talk.start.para: âI want to hail the success of the government's International Year of Older Persons program and its celebrations. Part of this program is the giving of Commonwealth Recognition Awards for Senior Australians, and I want to congratulate the Minister for Aged Care, Mrs Bishop, on its success. There have been a number of excellent nominations from a wide cross-section of the community in my electorate of Fisher. The most outstanding winner will come to Canberra in November to celebrate the International Year of Older Persons with representatives of other federal electorates. All of these people have contributed, and continue to contribute, to our community in a number of special ways.

speech.para: The leading nominee in Fisher, as selected by the committee, is Mrs Nan Cullemore, who established Meals on Wheels in Caloundra and has looked after this wonderful facility for many years. Nan is very well known in the community and has been a tireless worker for the elderly and those less fortunate on the Sunshine Coast. She is thoroughly deserving of this award, and I look forward to seeing her in Canberra in November to celebrate the International Year of Older Persons.

Other awardees include Janet Okines, a former President of the Sunshine Coast Art Group, who has managed a three-stage construction of the Sunshine Coast Art Group Centre, and Agnus Crosthwaite, who runs the craft group at Buderim Gardens with as many as 60 members assisting in a number of community groups with their craft work.

Bruce Weston has lived on the Sunshine Coast for 30 years and, during that time, has been a foundation member of Kawana Waters Bowls Club, where he was on the committee for a number of years. Eight years ago, Bruce formed the Kawana Senior Citizens Association and is still a very active member.

Mrs Maureen Kingston has been actively involved in the community for over 30 years. She was the first National President of the Association of Independent Retirees and has spearheaded many changes in government legislation. She was also awarded a Medal of the Order of Australia in 1995 and in 1996 she was appointed by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to the Conference for Older Australians.

Mr Herbert Fielding, who is 91 years old, has made an outstanding contribution to the Sunshine Coast community for many years. He was Captain and Treasurer of the Buderim Cricket Club in the 1930s and Secretary-Treasurer of the Buderim School of Arts. He has also been involved in many other ways.

Mr Edward Field has been active on the Sunshine Coast lawn bowls scene for many years and is currently manager of the district team and chairman of the coaching panel. Mr Des Dobson, at 81 years of age and a war veteran, has established a rainforest in his backyard and has planted over 200 native trees.

The Reverend Thomas Scarlett served with the HMAS Canberra and the HMAS Shropshire and, following the war, entered the Methodist ministry and eventually served as President of the Conference for the Methodist Church in Queensland. Margaret Thomas has been a leading advocate for the Red Cross. Gifford Milner has been active in the Golden Beach community since 1990. Mr Ron Warwick is donating his kidney to his grandson Riley, and the operation is in Melbourne today. I wish him and his grandson all the best.

Mrs Ailsa Mountney set up the first government funded child-care centre in Queensland. Mick Graham is a former union official and a very active member of the Golden Beach community. Jan Picton has worked for over 10 years to encourage older Australians to participate in exercise, and Maria Dregmans established the Maroochydore Share and Care Association 22 years ago. I congratulate all of these wonderful senior citizens on their awards.

talk.start.para: âOrder! In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

debate.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: âCassandra was given the gift of prophecy and the curse that she would never be believed and, like Cassandra, many people raised their voices to predict the tragedy that is currently occurring in East Timor. Their fate and the fate of the East Timorese people has been to be ignored until it was almost too late. When Portugal withdrew from East Timor almost a quarter of a century ago, it was easy to predict the Indonesian response. A nod and a wink from the international community and the fate of the East Timorese people was sealed.

speech.para: The outcome of this ballot and the violent aftermath were also predicted and these predictions ignored. The overwhelming support for independence has not been a surprise to anyone who has taken an interest in East Timor. Indeed, the East Timorese community in Sydney were confident about the results of the UN sponsored ballot; they were confident that it would be an overwhelming vote for independence. Militia leaders knew this and made no secret of the fact that they would not respect the outcome of the ballot if the result was for independence. Interviews with militia leaders on Australian television meant that every Australian knew what the Minister for Foreign Affairs claims not to have knownâthat the potential for violence after the ballot was high.

There is no question that adequate security arrangements should have been made for the ballot. It was at this stage that Australia should have called for post-ballot arrangements which guaranteed the safety of the East Timorese. Instead, we took the side of the Indonesian government against the United Nations and Portugal. Sections of our own security organisation warned the government of the potential for violence. Indeed, as early as 4 March, our Defence Intelligence Organisation gave the government a clear assessment of the role of the Indonesian military in the ongoing violence in East Timor. They said that the Indonesian military were `clearly protecting and in some cases operating with' pro-integrationist militias and that the Indonesian military, if it wanted to, could control such groups but had chosen not to.

The DIO warned that General Wiranto was at least turning a blind eye to the involvement of Indonesian military forces and that violence would certainly continue. With this background knowledge, the government continue to claim that they were unprepared because no-one could have predicted this violence. Not only could this violence have been predicted, it wasânot just by our own DIO but also by the Australians who were on the ground in the lead-up to the ballot and by Bishop Barreto, who so tragically lost his life in the violence he predicted. The massacre in Liquica should have been warning enough on its own.

Once again, Australia has let East Timor down. We seem destined to repeat our tragic history in this area. We deserted our friends after World War II; we abandoned them to their fate in 1975; and now we have urged them to participate fully in a UN ballot for self-determination and deserted them in their hour of need. Implicit in our support for the ballot was a promise not only that any process run by the United Nations would deliver a fair and democratic outcome but that that outcome would include the safety of the East Timorese people participating in the ballot. Australian journalists asked people who were queuing up to vote how they would vote. What has happened now to those people who told the world that they supported independence?

After the murders and destruction, especially of the last two weeks, an overwhelming majority of Australians will be pleased that a United Nations peacekeeping operation has begun in East Timor. Australians have long felt a special bond with the people of East Timor, who risked their lives side by side with Australian soldiers in World War II. I recently submitted a petition with 4,000 names calling for the Australian government to protect the people of East Timor. These were ordinary Australians who have long been far ahead of their political leaders in recognising the right of East Timor to self-determination. I hope, and I know that the people of Sydney hope, that Australia's involvement will save lives in East Timor. All our thoughts are with the East Timorese people and the brave Australians who are standing side by side with them to build a peaceful nation.

Sending in peacekeepers is not the end of the struggle; it is only a beginning. The challenge for the East Timorese people is to build a new nation, and I believe Australians want to be there supporting that nation building process from the beginning right through to the end. Of course, the first step is to stop the violence, the murders and the destruction of property. The disarming of militias is integral to this. The other immediate priority is to get food, water and medical supplies to those tens, or hundreds, of thousands who have been displaced. Indeed, it could be that the situation now in West Timor is as urgent as, or more urgent than, the situation in Dili.

It is only then that the process of rebuilding East Timor can truly begin. We face a situation where the major physical infrastructure of the capital, Dili, has been completely destroyed. Australians arriving in Dili as part of the peacekeeping operation have described a town where hardly a building has been left intact. Medical facilities and food distribution systems will all need to be built from scratch as a priority. This is still just the start. The East Timorese people will need to develop an independent system of government, a judicial system, an education system and a civilian police forceâthe infrastructure of civil society. Australia must now be prepared to commit resources in the long term to this task and to encourage the involvement of the international community. We cannot allow the world to turn its back when this is no longer the lead item on the nightly news.

The challenge for Australia is to take a long-term role in supporting nation building in East Timor. This means an increase in our aid budget. The international community must also address the issue of East Timorese who have been forced into West Timor or other parts of Indonesia. They cannot be left at the mercy of nationalist sentiment in other parts of Indonesia. We have to ensure that humanitarian organisations have adequate access, we must help the Timorese bring the perpetrators of recent violence to justice, and we should immediately remove de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor.

There is an additional challenge which has not been spoken of much at this time when our attention is focused so much on East Timorese people and the Australian troops who are in East Timor at the moment. But we must distinguish between the ordinary people of Indonesia and sections of the military. Many ordinary Indonesians will tell you that they believe their army to be unresponsive to the demands of the civilian government, that it has a will of its own. As a nation, we must continue to seek a peaceful resolution to this conflict with a minimum of lives lost and to make some distinction between the nationalists and the militarists in the Indonesian army and the ordinary Indonesians who may well support East Timorese independence.

Had this government not destroyed Radio Australia in its usual short-sighted way, we would now have a resource which would allow us to communicate directly with our troops in East Timor and also with civilians in East Timor and with ordinary Indonesians, many of whom may well be unaware of the extent of the horrors in East Timor today.
Finally, this measure is welcomed by all Australians. It is overdue. My constituents and I wish the Australian forces serving in East Timor the best of luck and a safe return.

talk.start.para: âBefore I call the next speaker, I would like to remind the committee that the question is that the paper be noted, and the paper we are talking about is the United Nations Security Council resolution of 15 September 1999. I have no difficulty with the debate being wide ranging over the subject, but I think it would be appropriate for speakers to at least give a passing mention to the subject of the debate.

âIt is never an easy decision in a liberal democracy such as ours to commit our armed forces to action overseas. The events in East Timor demanded that such a commitment be made, and the Australian government has shown leadership in responding to the East Timorese tragedy.

speech.para: Following the East Timor ballot agreed to by Indonesia, Portugal and the United Nations, the international community was presented with an unambiguous vote for independence by the people of East Timor. Honourable members will need no reminding of Indonesian obligations to maintain order in East Timor during the vote and during the transition to independence following the vote. But, despite assurances that its outcome would be respected, what followed the ballot was killing, arson, the exodus of refugees, the removal of East Timorese and the militia running riot. The imposition of martial law made no impact on this. It was transparent for all to see that Indonesian forces would not or could not stem the lawlessness.

The violence inflicted on the people of East Timor following the free expression of their will was something that Australia and the international community could not condone. As the situation deteriorated rapidly the world saw the devastation wrought on the East Timorese people, and it became clear that the only effective means of response was the deployment of an international peacekeeping force. The Indonesian government initially indicated that it would not agree to such a force, and it was only after considerable diplomatic effort by Australia and other countries that the Indonesian government accepted such a force being sent to East Timor. Last week the United Nations Security Council carried resolution 1264 authorising the establishment of a multinational peacekeeping force to restore order to East Timor.

Australia is to lead that force with a contingent that represents the largest Australian Defence Force deployment in a generation. We are well placed to lead that force because we have enhanced our operational readiness and made ourselves available to respond to United Nations requests. Australia and, in particular, the Prime Minister have been vital in bringing the force together. I do not think we should underestimate the enormous scope of that diplomatic achievement.

The United Nations resolution has been passed in record time. Joining Australia in INTERFET are Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, New Zealand, the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, France, Brazil, Italy and Malaysia; and many other countries have expressed a willingness to contribute. I think it is noteworthy that there is significant Asian participation in the force.

INTERFET, under Australian leadership, is tasked with restoring peace and security, the protection of the United Nations mission and the facilitation of humanitarian aid. Australia is now seeking to make a substantial contribution towards not only translating the referendum outcome into a peaceful reality but also significantly alleviating the serious humanitarian crisis that has developed.

The Australian peacekeepers follow in the footsteps of other Australians: the Federal Police, military liaison officers, consular officials and the United Nations workers who have worked under extremely adverse conditions to alleviate the suffering of the East Timorese. No-one in this place, I believe, underestimates the danger involved for the peacekeepers, for the Australians and for personnel from other nations who are participating in the INTERFET force. Standing up when it counts does often entail serious risks.

The loss of life, the driving of people from their homes and the indiscriminate violence that has been the recent history of East Timor remind us that we live in a region beset by stark difficulties. I do not think anyone believes that the difficulties in East Timor will be resolved overnight. Indeed, our commitment there, like the commitment of other nations, is likely to be a protracted one, involving several phases of UN peacekeeping if we are to do the job that is expected of us.

Today much of East Timor is in ruins. Even if peace were to be restored quicklyâas is surely the fondest hope of all of us hereâmuch would remain to be done. The aid and assistance required for reconstruction will be significant. We will have future obligations to the rebuilding of Timor, its infrastructure and its transitional political stability as it evolves into an independent state. These are important obligations, and I believe the leadership which the Prime Minister has displayed during this period of crisis and the overwhelming outpouring of support by the people of Australia ensure that Australia continues to carry out its commitment to the people of East Timor.

Australia is proud of the role that its forces are performing in East Timor. The people of Timor have been subjected to the most appalling devastation. The Australian forces will be coming to the assistance of those in distress to restore peace and security to the population of East Timor. But let us not forget that, even though our forces have been provided with a clear mandate and rules of engagement allowing them not only to defend themselves but to use appropriate levels of force to fulfil their UN mandate, our forces, our military personnel, are in harm's way. They, their families and their loved ones must have our continued support, assistance and backing. We are proud of the efforts of our forces and we pray for their success and safety.

talk.start.para: âI am grateful for the opportunity to speak in this debate to note the United Nations Security Council resolution which centrally raises the question of the crisis in East Timor and the issue of bringing peace there. As a representative of this parliament I had the opportunity to travel to West Timor in June this year to act as an international observer in the Indonesian elections. During the week that I spent in Kupang and in the outlying areas of West Timor, the issue of East Timor was raised with me and with our party on a number of occasions as we travelled. Already there were refugee camps on the border between East Timor and West Timor, with displaced persons gathering there because of militia activity in East Timor. Already the question of insurgency across the border from West Timor to East Timor was being debated and addressed and was well known throughout West Timor.

speech.para: As I travelled throughout West Timor accompanied by a member of our Department of Defence, Steve Lyon, our driver was an East Timorese man called Vince. He talked to us, during that week, of growing up in East Timor as an orphan, of being brought up by his brother and of his family who remained in East Timor. Given the heartbreaking events that have happened since the June Indonesian election, I can only wonder now where he is and how he is faring in the current circumstances.

While in West Timor I also met and talked with an East Timorese man who told me how he remembers his family, when he was a young boy during World War II, assisting an Australian soldier to hide from the Japanese. He told me how he would take a branch off a tree and brush the ground with it to obscure the Australian soldier's footsteps to prevent him from being tracked. Once again I can only wonder how this man is faring now.

These are, I know, small incidents, personal incidents, but they have put a face and a name to this tragedy for me. And what a tragedy it isâthousands killed, hundreds of thousands displaced. Having travelled in West Timorâand I think my colleagues are right to say that perhaps the greatest humanitarian crisis is now in West Timor rather than East TimorâI am left with an impression of how poor a nation it was before this crisis and what a disaster it must be now with hundreds of thousands of displaced people.

When you travel in Kupang you are at one minute outside a two-storey or three-storey building and 50 yards down the road you are in a village atmosphere, with pigs tied to stakes and goats wandering freely. When we travelled to the outlying areas in West Timor we saw the critical health and nutrition problems that the people there were already struggling with. You would walk through villages where women would have the goitre lumps visible in their necks from insufficient iodine in their dietâhealth problems that are unimaginable to us in Australia today and that are easily resolved through the provision of iodised salt.

That was the situation in West Timor in June when, apart from the refugee problem at the border between West Timor and East Timor, in reality the West Timorese were just trying to go about their business and feed and clothe and look after their own health care needs. Given that they were struggling with poverty then, with the question of nutritional problems then, with grievous health problems thenâand I spoke to a nurse who worked in the outlying villages trying to provide what health care could be provided in West Timor; there were already major health problems facing the West Timorese peopleâyou can only imagine how far that humanitarian problem must now be multiplied when, on an already poor and struggling place, you put hundreds of thousands of displaced people who have come presumably with no more than the clothes on their backs and who have critical needs for water, food, medical assistance, shelter and everything else that goes with looking after hundreds of thousands of people. We can only imagine, and never feel, the real need in the circumstances that must be in West Timor now.

Moving from those issues, I suppose that, having participated in the Indonesian ballot, the thing that has struck me as the events of the last few weeks have unfolded is how critical and, indeed, depressing it has been to move from the triumph which was the Indonesian ballot for its own election in June to the tragedy that we have now. In the course of the Indonesian elections, as our team moved throughout West Timor and other Australian observers moved throughout the other provinces of Indonesia, we were all struck by how peaceful, how ordered and how enthusiastic the Indonesian people were about having their first free and fair election in 35 years: a triumph of democracy, certainly a transitional democracy, not without some forms of trouble on the day but generally peaceful and generally participated in with an enthusiastic spirit.

One wonders now, as the events associated with the East Timorese crisis unfold in Jakarta, whether or not the birth of Indonesian democracy will turn out to be a stillbirth or a birth that is delayed in getting to maturity because of the impact of this crisis. It would be a tragedy indeed to see the enthusiasm which accompanied the Indonesian ballot dissipate and to see some form of undemocratic rule once again assert itself in Indonesia. But that might well be the consequence of where we are now.

The other thing that struck me as we travelled throughout West Timor monitoring that ballot was how welcoming people were of Australians and how reassuring they found our presence as we assisted with the Indonesian election. The very fact that there were international people there watching the election provided a form of reassurance to the people that it would be free and fair. We were emblazoned well and truly as Australians, with caps and T-shirts with the Australian flag on them and with lettering in bahasa which declared us to be part of the Australian election monitoring team. Wherever we went, no matter how far out into the West Timorese provinces, we were greeted with smiles and enthusiasm, and there was obviously a real affection for Australians amongst the people.

It is once again a tragedy that, as the events have unfolded in East Timor, that is no longer the case, either in East Timor or in Indonesia generally, and that the Australian-Indonesian relationshipânot only at the elite level but also between the peoplesâhas suffered so grievously during this process. I think that is something that ought to concern us now and concern us over the next few years, because to have a good relationship between our people and the people of Indonesia is obviously where we want to be.
In the debate yesterday, in respect of the whole issue of East Timor and the course that Australia has charted, the Prime Minister said:
Ours has been the correct and only responsible course of action.

I must confess I am left a little, I suppose, disturbed by that commentâ`disturbed' is probably the best wordâbecause I find it impossible that we are able to conclude that, when tens of thousands of people have died, when hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced, there was no other course of action that could have got us to a better result. How can a course of action that has those consequences be the correct course of action? Are we so intellectually and morally limited that a course of action that results in those sorts of grievous problems can be described by us as the `only responsible course of action'?

I believe there had to be a better way and our shadow minister Laurie Brereton for many months now has been pointing to a better way. A better way would have been to secure the East Timorese people and the province through peacekeepers fielded before the ballotânot afterwardsâand not to allow the many days to pass between the ballot and the outbreak of real violence in East Timor and the time that peacekeepers have actually arrived. None of us should sit here in some self-congratulatory way saying that we have done the right thing. Clearly, if that has been the outcome, we cannot have done the right thing. It is impossible.

Before I conclude my remarks, I would like to say that I have had the opportunity, and indeed my colleague from Melbourne Ports who is next to me has had the opportunity as well, to travel to Lavarack Barracks in Townsville and to meet with a number of people who now would have been deployed to East Timor as part of the peacekeeping force. When we travelled there, which was the week before this session of parliament reconvened, already the troops were talking about the likelihood, as they then believed, of going to East Timor and their readiness and, I would have to say, enthusiasm to do so.

Having met some of those people face to face, my thoughts are well and truly with them. I trust that, as a parliament and as a government, everything that can be provided to them is provided and that every step that can be taken to make their way easier is taken. Those troops in part have a connection with my electorate because it houses the language school at Point Cook. Many of the people who have been fielded in this deployment and who can speak the local languages would have undertaken that language training in my electorate. Once again, my thoughts are with them as they go about this very dangerous and difficult work. We wish them all the best.

talk.start.para: âIt is an honour today to rise in support of the United Nations Security Council resolution on East Timor. As Australians, we often take for granted the fact that we live in a democracy. We often do not consciously consider how lucky we are to live in a country where we can think freely and voice our public opinions in the open without fear of retribution. We tend to take for granted that we live in a country which, at its heart, is founded on all-round equality. We enjoy equal rights and being treated with equal respect regardless of race, colour, creed or origin.

speech.para: Australians who are born in this country are blessed with democratic rights. Those people whose birthplaces are outside Australia and who join the formal membership of the community of the Commonwealth by becoming Australian citizens also have the rights to freedom of expression and to sharing democratic beliefs.

Unlike Australia, freedom of rights was not automatic in East Timor. Two weeks ago, the people of the territory had the opportunity to express their views and to chart their future through the implementation of a ballot. The United Nations carried out an operation to allow independence to be born in the territory. Instead, this operation came with a blatant assault on the rights of thousands of innocent civilians.

During the Four Corners report on the ABC last Monday evening, we heard from many United Nations observers who had been stationed in Dili during the ballot process. They said that while few words were exchanged by the East Timorese people during the vote, there was a sense of relief that these people were free to have a say in their own future.

As we have heard on many occasions since the result, more than 78 per cent of the people voted for independence. As the result was announced, there were waves of emotion and scenes of liberation as families, friends and strangers hugged one another. This euphoria was short lived.

Recent events in Indonesia have galvanised Australian public opinion, activating an overwhelming response in favour of Australia taking steps to stop the escalation of violence and the campaign of terror being waged by the militias against the East Timorese people.

My office, like those of all federal MPs, has been inundated with telephone calls, faxes, emails and letters calling on the Australian government to help with the humanitarian tragedy. We have done so. Like other nations who have joined us in the peacekeeping mission, we could not sit back and watch.

Likewise, we could not initially allow our Australian troops to enter East Timor without the support of the United Nations and full agreement of the Indonesian government. We could not have gone into East Timor until President Habibie was persuaded to accept a peacekeeping force.

Contrary to what the opposition has said, the Australian government did not turn a blind eye to the suffering of the East Timorese people. We acted in the best interests of the nation. We took a leadership role and we have gained the support of other nations in the region to restore peace in East Timor.

The Australian government has been and remains steadfastly committed to ensuring that the wishes of the people of East Timor are honoured, that independence is granted and that the ballot result is protected and carried out.

As the Prime Minister has said on many occasions, Australia's aim is to achieve a situation in East Timor where a multinational peacekeeping force can supervise the peaceful transition to independence of the territory.

In the past two weeks the Australian community has experienced a sense of frustration and mixed emotions as we have witnessed, from the comfort of our homes, the devastation of East Timor and the displacement of thousands of East Timorese people. We have watched and read stories of killings, intimidation, displacement and destruction of property.

As I, along with millions of other Australians, watched the Prime Minister deliver his address to the nation on Sunday night, I reminded myself that thousands of people are reported to have died at the hands of armed militiamen and that the humanitarian crisis has claimed many more lives. As the Prime Minister said, the Commonwealth government's decision to commit Australian troops to the multinational peacekeeping operation in East Timor was not taken lightly. The decision was made in the national interest and to ensure that the UN process moves back on track so that the will of the East Timorese people is implemented.

I strongly support a move for the United Nations High Commissioner, Mary Robinson, to pursue the establishment of an international commission to investigate human rights violations in East Timor. I passionately encourage and champion the establishment of an international commission to gather and analyse evidence of the events in East Timor. There must be accountability for the violations against human rights. It is necessary that the United Nations sends a message that we do not condone such suffering. It is vital that justice is done on behalf of those innocent victims who have fallen prey to the militia.
I quote Mrs Robinson:

To grant amnesty to the authors of the most atrocious crime for the sake of peace and reconciliation may be tempting, but it contradicts the purpose and principles of the UN Charter. To end the century and the millennium tolerating impunity for those guilty of these shocking violations would be a betrayal of everything the UN stands for, regarding the universal promotion and protection of human rights.

Earlier this week, as we watched on our television screens the first troops leave for East Timor, all Australians' hearts went out with them and remain with them as well as their families. To those brave men and women go our prayers and hopes that they will remain safe and well.

Last Friday I was speaking with a military man at Canungra army base in Queensland. His son aged 21 was one of the 2,000 young men and women who have been deployed to East Timor to restore peace and stabilisation, to protect the United Nations Mission and facilitate humanitarian aid. His son was one of those 2,000 young men and women who are highly trained and capable to participate in our nation's largest military engagement for 30 years.

Australians are not only proud of each individual participating, but confident that they have the skills and training to achieve their objectives. As the Prime Minister stressed in his address on Sunday evening, our soldiers go into East Timor as part of a great Australian military tradition which has never sought to impose the will of this country on others, but only to defend what is right.

Finally, I want to say that I support the United Nations Security Council resolution on East Timor and congratulate the Prime Minister, the foreign minister and the Minister for Defence for the role they have each played in achieving what I believe to be a positive outcome to a very delicate situation. Australia does not want to be in conflict with our nearest Asian neighbour. We want to be part of a resolution to the situation and ensure for the future that we have a strong, balanced relationship with Indonesia based on mutual respect, stability and cooperation.

The Prime Minister, on behalf of the Australian government, has responded to the crisis in East Timor with leadership and measured determination. The practical and balanced proposals that the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Defence have pursued will hopefully bring peace to this troubled region and work towards strengthening our relationship in the long term with Indonesia.

talk.start.para: âFrom the outset, I want to make it very clear that I wholly support the motion that is before the chamber. As we have seen over the last few weeks, the support of the Australian community for the people of East Timor is indeed overwhelming, and that sentiment has now been expanded to be expressed towards those Australian soldiers who have taken the lead in forming part of the international peacekeeping force which has now been deployed to East Timor.

speech.para: The unanimous support for the motion that is before the chamber will send a very clear and important message. It is a message to both the Australian and international communities that the Australian parliament is very serious about assisting in the search for a peaceful solution to the current situation in East Timor. The only solution is the cessation of violence in order for the East Timorese people to be able to live in safety and to live in the way for which they have voted overwhelmingly in the last few weeksâas an independent nation.

The annexation of East Timor by Indonesia has had a devastating impact on the East Timorese people. Estimates have been made that between 100,000 and 200,000 East Timorese have lost their lives as a direct result of the conflict in East Timor over the last 24 years. Over the last few weeks, we have all seen the destruction of Dili and the murder of thousands. The television coverage of the situation in East Timor has been disturbing, but it has brought home to the Australian community the importance of Australian participation in moves to assist the East Timorese.

The government's recent actions in the leadership of the multinational force which entered East Timor yesterday need to be congratulated. I also take this opportunity to join with the people of Australia to applaud the decision to deploy Australian troops in East Timor to keep and enforce the peace.
I completely agree with the Leader of the Opposition who, on the departure of our troops for East Timor, said:

. . . all forces in Australian politics, all parts of the Australian community are right behind our troops in the endeavour that they are undertaking here on behalf of our country, on behalf of the East Timorese people, on behalf too of good order and stability in the region in which we live.

However, I am very concerned that the situation in East Timor has degenerated without the Australian government having adequately prepared for these very predictable circumstances. According to the shadow minister for foreign affairs, the member for Kingsford-Smith, there are two main reasons for the situation in East Timor reaching this crisis point.

First, there was the decision to allow the independence process to move quickly and to disregard the intelligence outlining the potential for bloodshed should the TNI remain in force with the so-called militia forces. There have been numerous accounts over the past months indicating quite clearly that the militia forces were operating with, at the very least, the tacit support of the Indonesian military.

Secondly, there was a delay in involving the United States. Once the US became diplomatically involved in the process of providing both United Nations and Indonesian sanction for a multinational force, the people of East Timor saw the formation of the force, which landed earlier this week.

In November 1998 Xanana Gusmao suggested a timetable for the territory to gain independence from Indonesia. The essence of it was that 18 months should be spent solving problems relating to security in that region, including disarming the paramilitary groups. That initial period was to be followed by a transition process lasting at least three years during which there would be a political education program and the establishment of an East Timorese police force, as part of a possible deployment of peacekeeping forces. Gusmao suggested that it might be a good idea for East Timor to have a decade of autonomy before a referendum on independence. Those sentiments were echoed by other East Timorese leaders, such as Ramos Horta and Bishop Belo. It is clear that these three people, so involved in the movement for an independent East Timor, felt that the safety of the East Timorese people was best ensured through a gradual process.

When it was decided that the East Timorese should vote as quickly as possible on whether they wanted autonomy within Indonesia or complete independence, neither the Australian Government nor the United Nations acted to oppose this decision. In fact, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs acted to expedite the process of independence. They ignored the views of the US Assistant Secretary of State that peacekeepers would be essential if the vote for independence was not to become a trigger for violence and retribution. The consequences of these inappropriate actions are there for all to seeâthe destruction of cities like Dili and their vital civil infrastructure, the creation of an enormous refugee problem within West Timor, the razing of the United Nations compound and, most seriously of all, the loss of thousands of lives.

Those are some separate points that can be made, but the overall sense that I know people in my community felt when they saw what happened in East Timor in the last few weeks was the understanding that we had betrayed the East Timorese people. The international communityâand Australia, as part of that communityâhas really led the East Timorese down the garden path without properly assessing the situation and responding to that assessment, which was quite clearly available to us.

The recognition by Xanana Gusmao of the potential violence and the need for the internal security of East Timor to be established was unfortunately not shared by the Australian Government. Indeed, it appears that intelligence reports indicated that there was a high risk of violence following the conduct of the ballot for independence. We have heard the grim predictions from the Defence Intelligence Organisation's report of 4 March a number of times in this debate and there is no need for me to repeat those. But it was quite clear that we had the available information in Australia to make a proper decision on how to deal with this vote for independence.

I believe that, through planning and with regard to appropriate risk assessments, much of the bloodshed in East Timor leading up to and following the independence ballot could have been avoided. What a different situation we would be dealing with right now if we had taken those steps in preparation for the ballot. I would have been saved the very difficult task of responding to things like this letter from a Year 7 student at the Sacred Heart school in my electorate. It reads:

Dear Ms Livermore, As a 12-year-old student and hearing, watching and reading the news this week, I feel disheartened because of all the bloodshed in East Timor. It is so close to home and the police and military who could have stopped it are standing back. I think it is Australia's duty to pressure the Indonesian Government to give the 78.5 per cent of East Timorese their voting wishâthat is, independence and peace. So please think about what I said and what is happening, such as innocent people dying at random by the militia.

Would it not have been much better for that Year 7 student to see the birth of democracy in a peaceful and orderly way in East Timor? What a great lesson in the power of freedom to achieve great results for a new nation. But how sad to have to say to him, `Well, the best we could do was to deploy peacekeepers after the event'âand after thousands of young children, just like him, had lost their lives.

Due to the lack of foresight by this government, and its apparent unwillingness to heed advice on the situation in East Timor, the Australian troopsâa significant proportion of the multinational forceâare entering a potentially dangerous situation. Like other members, I have received a huge amount of correspondence regarding the situation in East Timor. First of all that correspondence was overwhelmingly in support of a peacekeeping force, and it now overwhelmingly expresses support for the individual soldiers who are going to East Timor and for their families in Australia who hope and pray that they will return safely.

The friends and families of Defence personnel are justifiably concerned about the safety of these Australians, but I believe they appreciate the importance of this commitment to peace. When entering the military, people are making a commitment to the security of Australia and, in times such as this, to the safety and security of our region as a whole. While these Defence personnel accept the risks associated with their career choice, where there are any movements into areas of conflict the potential for harm increases and our appreciation for what they achieve for our country deepens. I wish to thank those people for their commitment to Australia and wish each of them a safe return home to their families and friends.

I would like to spend a short time in my speech to pay tribute to the people of my community of Central Queensland. They have shown themselves to be very compassionate in a number of situations this yearâfirstly, with their expression of care and goodwill towards the people of Kosovo and now to the people of East Timor. In a matter of only a couple of days, we were able to circulate a petition that attracted well over 700 signatures from schools, churches and community organisations in Capricornia. I thank the people of Capricornia for sending that very strong message to the Australian government through that petition.

I would also like to recognise the efforts of our community and church leaders in Capricornia in leading the way. When the history of the last few weeks is written, the actions of the Australian government will certainly be under scrutiny, but the moral authority that the Australian people have shown in their swift and very compassionate response to East Timor will be seen as the true legacy that we have from this situation. I wish the soldiers well, and I hope that we see peace in East Timor in a very short space of time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak in support of this motion and, in doing so, I want to commence by congratulating the Prime Minister for the vision, skill and leadership that he has given in this most difficult international tragedy. No repetition in this place of the vision of human beings cut down with machetes can make it any more awful than the truth of what has occurred. What we needed in this time was strong leadership to bring together a force under the United Nations which would act to bring pressure to bear on the government of Indonesia to allow a peacekeeping force to enter that land and bring about peace.

speech.para: Invasion was never an option. The Prime Minister, using all the negotiation skill that we could have wished him to have in this situation, brought about a result of which I can personally say I am enormously proud. As I walk the streets in Australia, I meet other citizens who say exactly the same thing. It was his ability to pull together, in a positive way, the nations who will join under Australian command the INTERFET peacekeeping force. I think you can truly say that would never have occurred without the Prime Minister. More than 12 countries will join this force. It is particularly important that we have people joining from the Philippines, Malaysia and New Zealand and that the Thai government is providing the second-in-command.

We ask of our ADF more than we ask of any other citizen in our land in terms of what they can be ordered to do and what impact that has on their own lives and that of their families. They are the only people whom can be ordered to go into a situation where their life can be ended. They recognise it. We recognise it. Their families live with it. They are people who accept that responsibility on behalf of the nation. They make me proud. I know they make the rest of the nation proud.

They are well trained. As a previous minister responsible for defence personnel, I can say that when I became that minister there was an ethos around that said, and it was repeated I think as late as 1995 by the previous government, that we really did not have to worry about anything much for 15 years, there was no real risk of military contingency.

We did not accept that. We did not accept the relaxed attitude that flowed from it and was perhaps epitomised by regarding our personnel as public servants in uniform. That is something we have never done, and never will do. They are special. They stand apart. Even in training their lives are at risk, as we saw in the Blackhawk tragedy when we lost so many of our able and well-trained personnel. But on this occasion I know that our troops, who we are deploying into the most dangerous environment we have entered in decades, are well trained. I know that they will do this nation proud.

As we think about the courage and the bravery that they will take with them we can well remember that our spirit of nationhood here in Australia was not forged in bloody revolution, rather, it was forged in bloody battle at Gallipoli. And the spirit of Anzac that came from that and grew from that is the spirit that is carried by our serving men and women today. They share that spirit of Anzac with our returned veterans who have fought for their country in so many wars over the rest of this century.

As the upholders of that tradition, they know that when our personnel fought at Gallipoli it was in a foreign land but it was for a cause that was right. They know, when they go now into East Timor, into a land that is not part of our Australian continent, that they are still going there to fight for something that is right. Their lives will be in jeopardy, as will be the lives of those who join with them, but in General Cosgrove we have a man in whom we can have great confidence.

It never gives a nation anything but trepidation to see our men and women deployed into a dangerous field, but it can give us a surge of pride to know that they are well trained, that they have a commitment to doing what is right, and to know that the cause that they are engaged in is one that has the full backing of the nation. I would like to think that the rather petty lack of bipartisanship that we saw yesterday could be put aside and that the same spirit of bipartisan support that was given to the deployment of personnel at the time of the Gulf War would be followed again now because our men and women who are going to that dangerous territory deserve no less.

talk.start.para: âI stand here today with mixed feelings as we debate this motion on East Timor. I have feelings of great relief that the United Nations peacekeeping force led by Australian troops has arrived to liberate the oppressed people of East Timor, but at the same time I also have feelings of great sadness because again my family is directly involved in conflict.

speech.para: My family has been involved in most of the conflicts that Australia has participated in in this century. My family has willingly answered the call of government to serve overseas and in Australia to protect the rights of democracy. I felt extremely proud, yet also sad, to see the youth of this country again answering the government's call to fight overseas. My nephew sailed out of Darwin at 6 o'clock on Saturday night as part of our Navy contingent taking personnel, equipment and supplies to the UN force in East Timor. My family is extremely proud of my nephew's involvement. However, his departure raises anxieties about the effect of involvement in conflicts on the families of service people.

I have personal experience of the effects of war. My brother Ron sailed on the Condamine to Korea and experienced the trauma of war. Fortunately, he returned safely. I hope that my nephew is spared the trauma of being fired upon and I look forward to his safe return.

I have also experienced what happens to families when the government fails to support returned personnel. I would like to share with you a passage of my first speech which deals specifically with past governments' failures to support returned service personnel and their families:
I was born into a caring family in the 1940s. However, at the end of World War II my father, a returned serviceman, left my mother with three children under the age of four years.

The government of the day provided little in the way of income support, public housing or support services to my mother and us childrenâor for my father, who I understand would have benefited from counselling and support services. Many returned servicemen have never fully recovered from their wartime experience. My family was one of many who suffered this experience.

There are other members of this House who have expressed the same anxieties regarding this lack of support. In his speech yesterday, the member for Cowan called on the Prime Minister to ensure that our East Timor troops are not treated in the same way as we have treated our Vietnam and Gulf War veterans. We owe it to the personnel and families involved in this conflict to make available debriefing and support services.

In community work and now as the member for Stirling, I have assisted veterans and their families in obtaining health services, family support services and I have also assisted them with appeals for benefits. From these experiences I have gained great respect for the role and work of the RSL clubs and Legacy in providing welfare services to veterans and their families. I would like to acknowledge the work done by the Nollamara-North Perth RSL sub-branch and the Osborne Park RSL sub-branch, both of which work hard for veterans and their families in my electorate.
But, to provide these services, more funding is needed. I will quote a brief passage of what the Prime Minister said yesterday in this House:

I was also very deeply warmed by the characteristic Australian responses. One of them looked at me as we ate and said, `Well, John, now I've got you, let me tell you what's wrong with the Army.' It was so Australian; it was so reassuring; and it was a reminder of the sorts of values that are important to the Australian community.
Well, let me tell the Prime Minister, on behalf of the veteran community, about what is wrong with support services. It is simple: they need more funding.

The sorts of values that are important to the Australian community include looking after the young men and women who place their lives on the line for their country. The member for Cowan, in his speech yesterday, identified this government's failure to provide justice for Vietnam veterans and their families, and its failure to hold an inquiry for Gulf War veterans into their health issues. I say to the Prime Minister, `You are committing our troops into an overseas conflict. Why don't you practise the values you spoke about yesterday and commit to providing justice to these veterans and to providing essential services to the East Timor service personnel and their families now? This would show that you and the government are genuinely committing to recognising the sacrifices they have made and may make, and the sacrifices that will be made in future by our service personnel.'

Another of the Australian values that the Prime Minister alluded to is supporting your friends and neighbours. This brings me to the plight of our friends and neighbours, the East Timorese people. I, like many Australians, have been sickened and saddened by the carnage in East Timor. The fact that the many people massacred were killed for exercising their democratic rights fills me and many other Australians with a sense of anger and outrage.

I have received many faxes, letters, phone calls, emails and visits from people in my electorate, as well as from people across the country. They all share this common theme: what can Australia do to stop these atrocities, and what support are we going to provide to the people of East Timor? Many of these people reminded me of our history in the region, and the assistance and support the East Timorese people gave to our World War II troops. These people also reminded me that we had promised the East Timorese people that we would always remember the torture and trauma they suffered when protecting the Australian troops.

There are East Timorese people living in my electorate and I am aware of torture and trauma they have suffered and the great distress they now experience in seeing and knowing what is happening in East Timor. As a community worker and activist, I was able to provide some service and assistance to the East Timorese community in Australia. I worked with such wonderful organisations as ASETTSâthe Association for Services to Torture and Trauma Survivorsâthe Friends of East Timor, the Northern Suburbs Migrant Resource Centre, the North Perth Migrant Resource Centre and the Catholic Migrant Resource Centre. I am aware from my experience how stretched these services are. With the arrival of more refugees from East Timor, these services will not be able to cope. I understand that some of these refugees will be placed in Leeuwin barracks, where the Kosovar refugees have been, so they will be in my area and they will be connecting with some of their family members and communities in the electorate.

Prime Minister, if we are going to honour our commitment to the East Timorese people, then you must address the issue of additional funding and resources now. The government talks about being preventive, about how much better it is to have preventive services and preventive programs so that, down the track, the health, counselling and housing budgets do not blow out because of the negative impact on people's lives which takes them into circumstances that end up costing the government a lot of money. The preventive measure is to have the services in place when the people arrive.

It took many years for the government to identify that many of the migrants who surfaced in our psychiatric system were really victims of torture and trauma and needed speciality services. It took many years to develop the kind of counselling services and model that ASETTS now provides to the victims of trauma and torture. We are aware of this, we have now commenced those services, but they are very stretched. As a community worker, I would find it would take many weeks to get people into the speciality counselling they needed because of the kind of torture and trauma they had suffered in their own countries before coming to Australia. Surely the preventive measure now is to look at the funding situation of these services and to increase funding now because we have additional East Timorese people arriving in Australia on a daily basis. All across Australia they will settle, not just in Western Australia or Sydney or Melbourne.

In supporting the government, I think what we have done in being part of the UN peacekeeping force is wonderful. What we need to do, what the government needs to look at and the coalition needs to support, are the important things that need to be done. I would now like to say that I support the motion.

talk.start.para: âI want to read to the House something the House may find interesting. I quote from Hansard :

speech.para: The Government welcomed the outcome of the talks last May and June in Dili and Macao between the Portuguese Government and the principal parties of Portuguese Timor. In our view, the program mapped out at Macao, providing for steady forward movement towards decolonisation and free elections for a constituent assembly, went a long way towards the objectives we support for the territory. It also follows, however, that the Government is most concerned by the present situation in Portuguese Timor. What began as a show of force by the UDT party on 10 August has deteriorated into virtual civil war with widespread loss of life. The UDT and the rival Fretilin party are struggling for power in Dili and in many parts of the interior.
