The Timorese police appear to have sided with UDT, while the much more numerous military is predominantly for Fretilin.

That was on 26 August 1975. On the following day, the Prime Minister, in response to a question from a Mr Ian Vinerâthe year is 1975 and the Prime Minister is Whitlam; I am quoting Whitlam, for the House's knowledgeâconcluded his answer to Viner's question on the second day of concerns being expressed at what was happening in Timor:

So we have been in touch with the ASEAN countries; we have been in touch, of course, with Portugal; we have been touch with the Secretary-General; we have been in touch with the Committee of Twenty-Four. We are making preparations, if it is desired, to transport Dr Santosâ
of the International Red Crossâ
and the advance representatives who are already here, to the island of Atauro to which the Governor of Portuguese Timor has transferred the seat of government.

He had talked to everybody but with no results. I would like to contrast, for the sake of the House, what occurred 25 years ago with what has happened over the last few weeks. The role which the government has taken in the last few weeks resolves those discussions that Prime Minister Whitlam held without any outcome, which produced just continuing concern and lack of support for any independence of Portuguese East Timor, as it was then known. Yet today, we have a Prime Minister of conservative outlook who has achieved what the great democrat himself could not achieve. Whitlam, who strolled the halls of power of the world proclaiming democracy, could not bring about what this government has achieved in Timor.

Whilst I do not wish to say this in a party boastful way because I know that the Labor Party in this instance is also supporting the outcomeâand that is a good thingâwe have achieved over the last few weeks what has taken 25 years to achieve. Some of the carping remarks of the opposition I do not think bear any really close examination. This attitude of `We're with you but we're going to be highly critical and, in a grudging way, say that Australia has done the right thing.' I do not think you achieve much by that. Constructive remarks, offers of support, assistance and advice from experience by past ministers for defence are helpful. But surely the Labor Party understands that the Australian people, as a nation, understand the seriousness of what has occurred in Timor and the seriousness of the situation in which Australia finds itself and in which we have placed ourself. We all acknowledge that the future is unclear but we must all acknowledge that we are proud of what we have done because we have done the right thing in Timor at last. We are going to get a resolution gradually of that process.

One of the advantages that we have in this relationship that we have with the Indonesian government is that there is a long history, encouraged by both sides of politics, of a close relationship with Indonesia. The professionalism of the armies and their close regard, respect and understanding of what the other one is up to is part of the success of what is occurring there now.

The handover from Indonesian army control to Australian-led UN forces has gone smoothly, basically because these professionals know and understand each other. Whilst we can misunderstand words, either deliberately or unintentionally here in this place, there is no misunderstanding of the codes of conduct with which either the peacekeeping group from the UN or the Indonesian army is going ahead. That is one of the brilliant things about what has occurred. No other nation could lead this changeover in a difficult period in the way in which Australia has and I pay tribute to the professionalism of the people who are involved.

It is interesting to look back over the process of the agreements and why the thing came unstuck. The tripartite agreement between Indonesia, Portugal and the UN on 5 May 1999 earlier this year has within itâright within the centre of itâthe statement:

Noting the position of the Government of Indonesia that the proposed special autonomy should be implemented only as an end solution to the question of East Timor with full recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor.

The stuff that the Labor Party was talking aboutâearly intervention and military presence at the polling boothsâis just sheer rubbish. The tripartite agreement clearly states the official Indonesian position. They are not going to wear it. In a treaty with Portugal, Indonesia and the UN, they made it clear they were holding sovereignty of that area and they continue to hold that position. The Portuguese position is clearly stated in the next paragraph:

Noting the position of the Government of Portugal that an autonomy regime should be transitional, not requiring recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor or the removal of East Timor from the list of Non-Self Governing Territories of the General Assembly, pending a final decision on the status of East Timor by the East Timorese people through an act of self-determination under the United Nations auspices.

That is the very centre of the agreement, the statement of difference. We have the Australian Labor Party saying, `You know Australia should have been tough and got in there, despite that agreement.' You cannot raise those arguments with any merit in this place.
The conditions of resolution 1246 adopted by the Security Council on 11 June 1999 are also of interest. Two of the paragraphs say:
Taking note of the pressing need for reconciliation between the various competing factions within East Timorâ
Welcoming the fruitful cooperation of the Government of Indonesia and the local authorities in East Timor with the United Nationsâ

This was a move towards the setting up of the process by which observers, the civilian police force and military liaison officers under the control of the UN supervised the referendum of self-determination.

What I would like to say on this issue is that, serious though the matters are, the future holds uncertainty. I believe that the Australian government needs to look at the processes of rollover and returns from Timor and at our reserve situation. The Australian Labor Party has been raising matters of workplace relations concern and the allowable matters for reservists to take time off to give service.

Of even greater significance, I believe, is the six weeks continuous service now required under the conditions of reserve service. I think that ought to be changed. There ought to be a more flexible approach than we have currently. The skills of semi-professionals and technologists who are in the reserve, or who would want to join the reserve, ought to be drawn upon by having a process which encourages them to affiliate with the Australian military. We cannot do this in the long term without the reserve. We cannot have a strong, established force without calling on the reserve. Our next steps over the next few weeks will be critical for Australia to maintain its presence and its strength in East Timor. I also encourage the Australian government to look at the resources of the Australian defence system to see whether or not we have gone as deep as we can into cutting expenditure and whether we ought to have a restoration of a reasonable expenditure on defence.

talk.start.para: âI fully support the motion on East Timor, moved by the Prime Minister:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) notes the overwhelming choice for independence exercised by the East Timorese people on 30 August;

(2) welcomes United Nations Security Council Resolution 1264 authorising a multinational force to restore peace and security in East Timor, protect the United Nations' mission in East Timor and facilitate humanitarian assistance;
(3) endorses Australia's agreement to the United Nations Secretary General's request that Australia contribute to and lead the multinational force;
(4) expresses its full support for the Australians serving with the multinational force and its full confidence in them; and
(5) looks forward to their safe return home.

I would like to start by congratulating the people of East Timor for their courage in voting for independence on 30 August this year. Unfortunately, although they achieved a result of over 78 per cent in favour of independence, the outcome for them has been catastrophic. They have taken great risks for independence and paid the highest price possible.

While we may argue here as to just how much we knew about the possible violence after the ballot, there is certainly no argument from the East Timorese people, because they knew very well what would transpire the day following the ballot. They knew, because they have seen the killing, they have seen the murder, and they were threatened before the ballot. But, in spite of all the threats, death and destruction, they went ahead with the ballot and voted for independence. Since that day, the East Timorese Australians that I know in Ipswich and Brisbane have been through a range of emotions and agonies of distress arising out of the violence from the militia and the military in their homeland. They are unable to contact their families and friends and are forced to watch daily while their country and people are destroyed.

It is a very dark time for the East Timorese people, but, despite these dark times, they maintain their vigilance and their struggle for peace and freedom. They have expressed to me relief in watching the international peacekeeping force setting foot in East Timor, in watching historic images of Australian and other soldiers walking along the streets of Dili and in seeing a professional army in East Timorâthe liberation force that will end the nightmare of 24 years and which has been very much welcomed by them.

As a nation, Australia should be proud of what we are doing. For Australia it is a clear break from our past policy. Some people have asked me why we need to do anything, why we should lead the peacekeeping force, or why we should send troops and commit money and resources. Well, that question is very easy to answerâit is because it is the right thing to do. It is a decent thing to help defenceless people being butchered. It is no less than what we would expect and hope others would do for us if we were ever in need.

Of course, some time ago we were in need. As is well known, during World War II our diggers engaged the Japanese in East Timor and if it were not for the courage and efforts of the East Timorese people then, many of our returned soldiers would not be here to tell us their stories. We made a promise to those people that in return for their support we would always be there for them. All they had to do was to call out and we would be there.

We all know this from history, but last week I had the privilege, at an Ipswich rally for East Timor, to speak to one of those returned soldiers. Stan Kent, a former commando, recounted to the rally how he survived in East Timor and fought the Japanese, but he made it very clear that he would never have returned if it were not for those people.

Stan Kent, like many others, knows exactly why we need to help and why East Timor is part of our responsibility. The thought that any civilised country such as ours could sit by and watch people being butchered and not help them is not an acceptable concept. The very basis of our society is that we will help our neighbours when in need. We cannot be an idle spectator. It is not who we are. This is an important part of our history, an important part of our heritage, and everything to do with what makes us uniquely Australian.

Like the people of East Timor, I believe we are a people of great forgiveness. That is why a clear distinction must be made here between the military and government, and the people of Indonesia. It is not the people of Indonesia who are to blame for they are victims of similar oppression as that faced by the people of East Timor. The blame lies squarely at the feet of the military and the militia. The military have run East Timor as a personal enclave for the past 24 years. They have used its resources and its people. They have raped and murdered. All this has happened while we, and the rest of the world, largely looked on or turned a blind eye.

The suffering over the last 24 years of the people of East Timor will be synonymous with the suffering of the people of Indonesia if the reign of the military is left unchecked by the Indonesian government. It will be up to the Indonesian government to take bold steps along a path in the direction of human rights and to start to redress these failings. It is a path that I believe they have started to travel. But make no mistake, it will be a long road.

It will also be up to the international community through economic pressure to ensure that human rights abuses are eliminated and that democratic processes evolve. It will also be up to the Australian government through aid and other means to help in this process. The damage that has occurred to Australia-Indonesia relations over the last few weeks will take a long, long time to repair. This is not an apology for the Indonesian government, military or militia, for they are very much responsible for what has happened and they should be held accountable. But the reality for Australia is that we are part of this region that includes Indonesia and in the future we will need to repair the relationship if we are to live free of animosity.

The relationship will have to be rebuilt if we are ever to help the people of East Timor and if they are to live in peace with their neighbour Indonesia. This must be done, but not at the expense of the people of East Timor or at the expense of human rights. This situation has demonstrated that Australia must take a bigger role in the region, that we should not rely too heavily on other countries for defence, and that we should take more seriously our defence force capabilities. The current level of about 50,000 ADF personnel is too low. Our country has one of the world's lowest expenditures on defence as a percentage of GDP, and our reserve force last year failed to recruit significant numbers and fell short by thousands of the required target. These are just facts, they are not criticisms.

These issues must be addressed as a matter of urgency. Australia needs to investigate our real defence needs. The government needs to ensure that our service personnel are given the best training, resources and support possible. It also needs to know that issues of family and remuneration and conditions are considered as important as the job they do. The troops need to know that Australia and the government are 100 per cent behind them in every respect.

Joe Teixeira, an East Timorese Australian from Brisbane, has organised a prayer vigil later this week for the East Timorese community to pray in solidarity and support with the Indonesian community in Brisbane. For a person who has lost 70 per cent of his family to the brutality of the Indonesian military and militia, this shows a level of understanding not many of us could fully appreciate. But this is not about the Indonesian people. As I have said before, this is about the Indonesian military and government.

The people of East Timor are talking about peace, forgiveness and reconciliation. For them to be speaking these words at this time demonstrates incredible courage and resilience. I would like to quote Joe Teixeira, who spoke to me at a recent rally in support of East Timorese people and our troops. He said:
We pray for the dead but we fight like hell for the living, and carrying out recriminations will not bring back our 300,000 dead.

What the people of East Timor are looking for is compassion and care from the Australian community to help rebuild their shattered lives. If we can do that as a community, we will help to build a civil society that not only the East Timorese people will be proud of but also the Australian people will be proud of.

The courage of these people can never be taken for granted. On the night of the ballot, Paul Toon, a community development worker from Brisbane, was sitting in the village of Lete Foho talking to a man who had been threatened by the militia. The man said:
If I die tonight before the ballot I have a problem, but if I die tomorrow then I have no problem because our children will carry forward our independence.

There are many stories of people who, immediately after the vote, packed up their belongings and headed for the hills because they knew they would be killed. But they still voted. This is the courage with which the East Timorese people voted for independence. Australia and the international community should have the courage to match this by pushing harder for a resolution that would include saving the East Timorese people now in prison in concentration camps in West Timor. The reality is that there is not much left in East Timorâeither people or infrastructure.

The need to be repatriated and helped to rebuild lives is the current great humanitarian need. In Brisbane, church and community groups have already established a coordinating committee to take volunteers to East Timor and to provide a safe haven for East Timorese asylum seekers in Australia. There are many people in my community who have to be thanked for their work. There are in fact too many to mention, but I would like to thank the Ipswich Churches Social Justice Group, the Ipswich City Council, the Ipswich Labor movement and the Ipswich and Brisbane East Timorese community.

I would like to pay particular thanks to the many service personnel who will be going over there. Many of them are my friends. I wish them very well in their peacekeeping. In closing, I want to make it very clear that I support the government on this motion and applaud their commitment to support our defence personnel and to help rebuild East Timor. Our thoughts are with our troops and their families. I pray that all our troops return quickly and safely. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âBefore calling the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, may I remind the chamber that the paper being noted is United Nations Security Council resolution 1264 and not the motion that was before the House yesterday.

âI am certainly pleased to speak to the motion before the Main Committee that the paper be noted and also to support the resolution passed in the House yesterday. In taking the opportunity to speak today, I am confident that I will be expressing the feelings of the people of Eden-Monaro in condemning the violence and destruction that has taken place over the past couple of weeks throughout East Timor and in sending best wishes to our troops in the peacekeeping force for a successful operation and a safe return. I particularly wanted to speak on this motion as I suspect I am one of the few federal members of parliament who have visited East Timor. I would like to take this opportunity to add some personal insights and experiences to this important debate.

speech.para: I did not visit East Timor with a parliamentary delegation or an official delegation. In fact, I visited East Timor in 1994âjust five years agoâin my previous occupation as a consulting surveyor. I travelled there by light aircraft from Darwin with a couple of my business colleagues to assess a variety of potential infrastructure projects. In thinking back now, I am reminded of just how close Timor is to that very northern part of Australia.

We took off from Darwin in a six-seater light aircraft to do a number of things while we were away. It was only a very short trip by light aircraft across the water from Darwin to Kupang in West Timor, where we went through immigration and customs. From Kupang, we crossed into East Timor, to Dili. It saddens me greatly to think that at that time we were looking at the sort of projects which were designed to assist the East Timorese to have access to some basic services, to help to develop new industriesâin short, to modernise and help them move forward.

Not only has much of that infrastructure that we looked at not occurred, but we have now had to witness the destruction of much of what they did have. I heard a news report only in the last few days that one of the main banks in the middle of Dili was still burning. I suspect that it is probably a bank in which I spent quite some time back in 1994, trying to weave my way through some complicated processes of changing some money. It was quite an interesting exercise that we went through. Even that sort of infrastructure has possibly been destroyed and will have to be rebuilt.

It also disturbs me to think of the many people who we met during that visit and to wonder about their fate. In that respect I would like to mention the Carrascalao family who were particularly helpful to us on that business trip. They gave us introductions in a variety of areas and helped us to work through some of the bureaucracy extremely well. I know that the Carrascalao family have lost many members of their family over the years because of the problems in East Timor. My last images of Manuel Carrascalao were at Dili airport when he successfully helped us to negotiate the release of our aircraft. Certain groups had decided they were going to take control of it and not allow us to take off without substantial monetary exchanges. It was terrific that the Carrascalao family were there to help us to get through some of those difficulties. At the end, they came racing out, saying, `Hang on, I've got to give you some coffee before you go,' so we got loaded up with some of their coffee to take with us. It certainly disturbs me to think of what might have happened to many of those people.

The people we met when we were there came from very diverse situations. Some, superficially, were working quite closely with the Indonesian bureaucracyâvery successfully, in factâwhile at the same time they were always planning for the day when they would have independence. I met others very late one evening, when I was taken to a safe location, who kept well clear of Indonesian officials. The coming together of these two groups was seen as dangerous and was only done with great care. I was honoured to have been part of some of those get-togethers at the time. I was privileged to have had the opportunity to discuss a range of matters with these two groups together.

I was able to get a very good insight into East Timorese history as a result, but it also made me aware that, at the same time, there were competing forces among the people advocating independence. On that particular evening, which I remember quite well, I met in a hotel with some people who were involved in business, who were working closely with the bureaucracy and were wanting to help to get up and going some of these infrastructure projects that we were looking at. They thought it was very necessary that we should meet with some of these other groups that you would not find during the day. So at about midnight one night, we were taken to a location to be able to meet with the various groups together and talk through the long-term future of East Timor. At that stage, in 1994, they certainly had no idea how long it might take before they might see independence.

I talked about the fact that there were competing forces, even within the independence groups at that time. Since that time, I understand that much has been achieved with respect to the unification of pro-independence groups. However, I believe that this will remain an area of high priority once peace is fully restored and the road to independence is further advanced.

There is no doubt that East Timor has some huge challenges ahead. From my recollection, very many difficulties will be faced in establishing basic infrastructure. For example, water supply alone is no easily solved problem. This was an area we were investigating in 1994. Many parts of East Timor are unique in that it is in the tropics but is often affected by rain shadows. This can, effectively, create drought type conditions when normally a wet season should be occurring.

I am sure Australia will have an ongoing involvement in East Timor well beyond its role in the international peacekeeping force. The rebuilding of East Timor alone will be a huge task and one in which Australian expertise can play a leading role. Hopefully, many of those infrastructure projects I was assessing back in 1994 will ultimately become a reality.

I would like to add my congratulations to the Prime Minister, John Howard, to the foreign minister, Alexander Downer, and to the defence minister, John Moore, for the superb job they have done during this most difficult time. Many people in my electorate have expressed their relief to me that John Howard was in charge. They have recognised his cool-headedness and the tremendous leadership he has shown. He has achieved something quite remarkable, considering the last 25 years' history of East Timor.

Allow me to read from one of the letters I have received in my electorate office. It comes from Mr Al Armstrong, from Edenâwho, quite coincidentally, was recently chosen by the electorate selection committee set up for the International Year of Older Persons as the person to represent Eden-Monaro for that celebration. I hope to talk a little bit more about that in the House at a later time. Mr Armstrong said:
Dear Gary,
Please convey my congratulations to the Prime Minister of Australia, for his speech on Prime Television to-night, Sunday 19/9/99.
I fully support as an individual, his . . . expression of opinion of the ability and the readiness of the Australian troops committed to the Peace Keeping Forces.
He then talks about some of his experiences in that region during the war, and finishes by saying:
Please pass these sentiments of total loyalty to your Government and Prime Minister, especially for the courage and dedication he has shown in this very critical time.
Yours faithfully,
Al Armstrong

In closing, on behalf of the people of Eden-Monaro I extend best wishes to all of our personnel involved in this operation in East Timor. I express our sympathy to the many East Timorese families who have gone virtually to hell and back in recent times, and certainly to many of the people whom I met during my time in East Timor in 1994, when they gave such assistance. I certainly feel for the difficulty that they have been through.
I wish our troops every success and hope that they are able to establish a peaceful and safe environment for East Timorese as soon as possible. I wish them a safe return to Australia.

talk.start.para: âAustralia's forces go to Timor with the full support of all members of this parliament and the overwhelming support of the Australian community because it is a moral cause: to stop murder, terror and destruction. It is an Australian responsibility to help our nearest neighbour, and it is in our national interestâto restore peace on our doorstep.

speech.para: We recognise that Australia's participation in this force may well be at a significant cost. There may be casualties. Putting young Australians in harm's way should never be done lightly. If the military involvement is protracted, as it may well be, it will have a high budgetary cost. When the situation is stabilised, Australia, amongst others, will have to make a significant contribution of foreign aid to help rebuild East Timor. We will also have to make a substantial contribution to assisting refugees.

Australia's intervention has meant a serious deterioration in our relationship with Indonesia. While we have contributed to a number of peacekeeping operations and the Gulf War, we have not faced issues of this magnitude so close to home for decades.

The position of Bishop Belo and those associated with Falintil was that there should be a lengthy period of transition, to facilitate reconciliation, followed by a ballot on independence. It is a tragedy that the views of those in a position to understand the forces at work in East Timor were not given more weight, not only by the Indonesian government but also by the Australian government and the rest of the international community.

Whatever our views about whether the circumstances now faced in Timor were either avoidable or capable of substantial mitigation, events unfortunately reached the situation where Australia and the international community had no other option but to act. When Timor became a holocaust, some Australians felt we should act unilaterally. Action of that kind would inevitably have made the situation worse. Whatever miscalculations had been made which precipitated the crisisâmiscalculations by Indonesia and the rest of the international communityâthey had been made months before, not in the days leading up to or following the ballot.

Unilateral action by Australia may have been interpreted as a hostile act. The worst scenarios flowing from that could quite possibly have been beyond the capabilities of the force Australia had prepared, and therefore the lives of a great many Australian soldiers would have been put in jeopardy. Whatever our views about a situation which did not directly threaten our territorial integrity or the lives and safety of Australians, it would have been a dangerous precedent to act alone when it was not only possible but appropriate to seek collective international intervention through the United Nations. The appropriate response was a multilateral one in cooperation within Indonesia.

Because of the situation into which Timor has descended, there is a risk that our involvement will be for a very considerable period. However long it takes, we have an obligation to ensure that we remain steadfast in our support for the military personnel we have committed to this task. That unwavering support must be maintained until the task is complete. And when the task is complete, if there are veterans who still bear a burden from their service on Timor when they have returned home, then that support must be continued.

Fortunately, the members of the Security Council who drafted resolution 1264 have learnt the bitter lessons of some recent United Nations peacekeeping operations. A United Nations presence can be inadequate to keep the peace if it is not given authority to `take all necessary measures' to fulfil that mandate. Massacres and acts of terror have actually occurred in the presence of United Nations forces because the perpetrators were aware that those forces did not have the necessary authority. Resolution 1264 gives that authority and, like any effective deterrent, in so doing greatly improves the chance that lethal force will not have to be used.

The difficulty of maintaining a peacekeeping operation in a potentially hostile environment cannot be overstated. It is important to recognise that the objectives of the multilateral force are entirely for the benefit of the East Timorese people. Resolution 1264 clearly defines them as: to restore peace and security in East Timor; to protect and support the United Nations mission in East Timor in carrying out its tasks; and, within force capabilities, to facilitate humanitarian operations.

The deployment of Australian military forces to lead International Force East Timor fulfils our moral obligation to our nearest neighbour. Australia had to act to stop the slaughter of innocent Timorese people. Ensuring peace in our region stands second only to the defence of Australia as a justification in the national interest for the use of force. It is a matter of deep regret that a peacekeeping force was not put into East Timor before the vote on independence. That could have both avoided the violence and greatly lessened the danger to peacekeeping forces. The Australian government needs to review in a rigorous way what additional actions it should have taken on the diplomatic front to influence these events.

What other lessons must we learn from this experience? While Australia is contributing 2,000 highly skilled military personnel to INTERFET, the operation has also been a demonstration of some of the limitations of our military capability. There is already some consensus that this is something that needs to be addressed and that there will be a need to increase defence spending. That will have two components. The first is the actual cost of the deployment. If it is protracted, it will become very significant with the need to rotate military personnel committed to the force. Secondly, there is the general question of how we should enhance our military capability. That does not necessarily mean that the lesson we have learnt is the need to have a long-term increase in the number of regular forces. Nor is it a reason to restructure our forces specifically to meet larger peacekeeping requirements. What has been demonstrated by this experience is that, as a country with a relatively small population, there are obviously limitations to the size of any force we can raise.

If we have found some of the limits of our capabilities in preparing for the East Timor operation, then we need to think carefully about how we should structure our forces to meet a worse contingency. Nothing that has happened in the last few days should move Australia from the fundamental principle that we should structure our military forces for the defence of Australia. If we do that and, unfortunately, it is a principle which the Howard government has drifted away from with notions of forward defence, then we will be in a much better position to deal with contingencies like East Timor.

There are two main components of that. The first is focusing on our capacity for expansion, which includes an appropriate and capable reserve element, such as the ready reserves which were established by the Hawke government, but sadly abolished by the Howard government. The second, given this demonstration of the inherent limitations of the size of force elements which we can mobilise, is that we need to focus on developing those capabilities which are necessary to meet higher level direct threats against Australia, principally our strike capabilities.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to support the motion before the chamber and particularly the United Nations Security Council resolution. In the world of Orwell's 1984 , `history was bunk'. The Orwellian state's public servants worked diligently at censoring and rewriting old newspapers, so that history would always apparently conform with whatever version of the truth the leadership wished to assign to it in line with changing international relationships. I have been reminded of Orwell's 1984 as I have listened to some intone piously about what the Howard government should have done on East Timor.

speech.para: It is certainly agreeable to find that an issue which one has done one's small bit to champion over the years, namely the independence of East Timor, has become fashionable. But I am here to remind the House that this was not always so. There are only a couple of faces that I can remember from the other side speaking out for East Timor and they were the member for Melbourne, Lindsay Tanner, and the member for Reid, Laurie Ferguson. Regrettably, there were few on this side either.

While I commend the member for Kingsford-Smith, Laurie Brereton, for breaking with official Labor Party policy on East Timor earlier this yearâit is certainly better late than neverâit must also be remembered that it involved a massive U-turn after 24 years of appeasement by the Labor Party, all the more marked because it had the power in government, both in 1975 when this problem arose and, more recently, to really make a difference, but it did not. The member for Kingsford-Smith made this remark yesterday:
One is always tempted by what might have been.
He went on:
Had we fulfilled our responsibilities, we could have prevented Timor's triumph from turning into tragedy.

Well, I am not going to resist this temptation. I will tell you what might have been. Had Paul Keating remained at the head of government, there would have been no pushing for any ballot for independence in East Timor for starters. Paul Keating, like all Australian leaders from Whitlam on, liked to think that we had a `special relationship' with Indonesia. Every time we made the mildest of objections to some dreadful infringement of human rights, we were quickly smacked on the wrist and we were made to go on our way with our tails between our legs. Had one been describing the relationship between two people, one would have described it as deeply dysfunctional and certainly masochistic on our side.

As there would have been no ballot, we probably would not have seen such a bloody maelstrom, but certainly the killings of East Timorese supporters of independence and anyone else who got in the way would have continued, though not on such a grand scale. We would have been left with the steady drip drip of routine violence and bloodshed in East Timor, and the Labor government would have continued to tell us that Indonesia would deal with its own internal security problems.

Let me take the chamber on a brief trip down memory lane to the first speech I gave on East Timor in this place in March 1992. That day I reminded the House of the Whitlam government's response to the invasion of East Timor in 1975; it endorsed it. The Liberal shadow foreign minister at the time, Andrew Peacock, at least protested the inactivity of the Whitlam government. The Whitlam government, as I said then, gave the green light to the invasion and sealed the fate of the East Timorese people.

Moving along in our time machine, let us revisit the Hawke Labor government's response to the 1991 churchyard massacre of over 100 people, including a New Zealand student studying in Australia. The then foreign minister, Gareth Evans, told us that the response of Indonesia was `credible'. He was quick to make sure that the crosses blessed by a Catholic priest set up outside the Indonesian Embassy in Canberra to represent the slain in East Timor were removed posthaste to appease Indonesian sensibilities.

What struck me in that debate in March 1992 was how apparently decent human beings on both sides of the House, in the matter of a small foreign territory, far too close for comfort, consumed like a rabbit by a very large boa constrictor next door, could be quite impervious to decency or humanitarian concern and be totally focused on the economic advantages of our relationship with Indonesia and our gains from the Timor Gap Treaty. In international relations, morality tends to become what we can afford or think we can afford. I said then that pragmatism is really only a euphemism for allowing practical exigencies to excuse anything at all.

Against this sorry background the Howard government's achievement on East Timor would not have been believable 12 months ago. It constitutes a revolution in Australia's foreign policy. Not only did the Habibie government consent to a ballot for East Timor, for which it should be given great credit, the Indonesians subsequently invited the UN to send in a peacekeeping force. None of this would have come about but for the enormous work done by the Prime Minister and the foreign minister in convincing the international community that it was the right thing to do to protect the people of East Timor and to support Indonesia in re-establishing order.

While the calls for immediate action by the Australian public have flooded into all our offices and people have been critical of the time it has taken, it should be remembered that it took only two weeks between the ballot result and the sending in of the peacekeepers, a world record for United Nations missions.

The various `might have beens' urged by the opposition belong to cloud-cuckoo-land. They are now manufacturing a new, seamless pseudo history where it would have been perfectly possible for the Indonesians to have been convinced both of the need for a ballot and for peacekeepers. The Prime Minister tells us that in his discussions with President Habibie, this was not possible, although it was suggested time and again to Indonesia. More importantly, China and Russia would have vetoed a peacekeeping force before the ballot. It took a vote of 78 per cent in favour of independence and, unfortunately and tragically, the mass slaughter and forced exodus of the East Timorese population that followed, to convince the international community that anything needed to be done. The opposition in this glib rewriting of history's possibilities tells us we could have kept good relations with Indonesia and secured the peacekeeping force for East Timor. This, I believe is just wishful thinking. It was obvious that Indonesia was going to be shocked and affronted by our sudden acquisition of moral sense after 24 years of craven appeasement at any cost.

The Prime Minister has been enabled to stand up for the people of East Timor and take a firm moral stance because he had the Australian people behind him. No member of this place could not have been moved by the enormous passion of ordinary, unallied Australians who protested their desire for the Howard government to go to the aid of little East Timor. I believe that this is the result of a sense of history. We have done this because we remember that during the last war 40,000 East Timorese people died, many of them helping Australian soldiers to survive in Japanese occupied territory. What we have seen in the Howard government's push for a ballot in East Timor and now our leadership of an international peace enforcing force, signifies a reversal of policy held for almost a quarter of a century by both parties in government. The holocaust of slaughter of men, women and little children who did nothing more than vote for independence has shown us that, as I said in my March 1992 speech, the price of appeasement is too high. That policy is now in the dustbin of history.

I believe that history will look kindly on the Prime Minister and give him the credit that is his due. I hope that we will be able to find some new and more genuine level of friendship with Indonesia and watch our neighbour grow in international prestige and esteem as its yet fragile democracy takes root. I sincerely hope that good may come from the terrible sacrifice made by the people of East Timor so that they may live free from fear in a prosperous new nation. We must not forget the hundreds of thousands of East Timorese people who find themselves stranded in West Timor in refugee camps or elsewhere and urge that they be permitted to return to East Timor.

If there is any glory to be had in this tale of suffering and endurance, it belongs to the brave people of East Timor. I would like to honour them today. In particular, I would like to mention an East Timorese leader, Mau Hodu, who came to Parliament House here in Canberra several months ago and addressed a meeting of Parliamentarians for East Timor and other people involved in this cause, a visit already mentioned in this discussion by the member for Calare. In the most recent information to hand, I have learned that Mau Hodu was taken into custody on 7th or 8th of September and transported to Kupang. He has not been heard of since then and there are fears that he is, in fact, dead. Mau Hodu represented both the gentleness and the strength of the East Timorese people and I would like to remember him here today. For those like him who have given their all for their country, I will end by saying, `Viva East Timor.'

talk.start.para: âLike many others, I have waited a long time to see the scenes that we have seen on Australian television over the past few days of Australian soldiers being greeted in Dili by the East Timorese people. Finally, after 25 years, we have found the courage and strength to take action to assist the East Timorese. I applaud the Australian soldiers who are making a commitment and putting their lives on the line, placing their lives at risk, in order to ensure that we can both restore our national honourâwipe out what has been a great source of national shame for Australia over 25 yearsâand make our contribution to ensuring that the East Timorese people who have not already suffered death as a result of the recent tragedy can look forward to building a new nation on the back of the independence vote that occurred a couple of weeks ago.

speech.para: I do not want to focus today on the policy failures of the Howard government in this respect. I think there have been policy failures by the Howard government but, as the honourable member for Menzies implicitly pointed out, all Australian governments have had failures with respect to East Timor going back into the mid-1970s. I think it is a fruitless exercise to try to determine who was more complicit in the failure of Australian policy on this issue since that time.

The fact is, a ballot has finally occurred. The East Timorese people have voted for independenceâas we always knew they would do. We now have peacekeepers there on the ground. We now have the opportunity to recover from the appalling tragedy that has occurred over the past few weeks. We now have the opportunity to assist the East Timorese people in building a new nation.

It is critical that we focus on the positives in this situation in spite of the appalling recent tragedies that have occurred. These recent tragedies, it is important to recall, are just another instalment in decades of tragedy for East Timor. They are not new, they are not novel, they are things that the East Timorese people have been living with for a very long time. But the positives are that finally, after 25 years, we have had a genuine expression of self-determination by the East Timorese people. They voted overwhelmingly for freedom. They voted overwhelmingly for independence. The positives are that these people have fought tenaciously against a brutal and corrupt authoritarian regime and against the oppression of invading occupiers. They have never resorted to terrorism against civilians. They have never bombed Jakarta. They have never used tactics other than simply attacking the invaders in their own country. And now they have an opportunity to build a new nation.

So, instead of wringing our hands about the cost that this may entail to Australia, or indeed focusing on the policy errors of the Howard government, let us commit ourselves to making sure that we can assist in the rebuilding of East Timor, help bring a new nation into being, and restore the freedom and democracy that these people are entitled to, just as anybody else in the world is entitled to.

I would like, however, to make one note of criticism of one group of people in Australia who deserve enormous condemnation for their role in the unfolding of the events over the past 25 years, and that is the pro-Indonesian lobby. That lobby comprises a handful of academics, journalists, diplomats and Australian foreign affairs officials who have been prepared to condone any atrocity no matter how extreme; who have been prepared to explain away any act of brutality or corruption by the Indonesian regime no matter how outrageous; and who have been prepared to applaud and apologise for the Suharto regime no matter how brutal it has been to its own people.

Sadly, these people have influenced some Australian politicians. I note that when the member for Farrer resigned as Deputy Prime Minister, none of the glowing media mentioned the fact that he was the same person who, only a couple of years ago, said that if we were looking for a man of the latter half of the 20th century we should look at President Suharto. In fact, if we were looking for one of the most brutal and corrupt dictators of the second half of the 20th century and one who was responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths, then President Suharto would have been a pretty serious contender.

So, this craven, myopic group who have foisted their views of how Australian foreign policy should operate onto Australian opinion leaders have got a lot to answer for. Yet, we have not heard one word of apology, not one word of retraction, not one word of recantation of their policy which they masqueraded as Realpolitik, as the appropriate thing to do, as the necessary thing to do, to ensure that we had good relationships with Indonesia.

This posturing ignores the reality of our relationship with Indonesia. Neither countryânot Indonesia, not Australiaâcan afford to have bad relations: Indonesia, because Australia is an economic power in the region and a strong military power; Australia, because Indonesia controls the shipping lanes and aviation access to our country. And there are many other issues. Both countries need good relations. Although it is understandable that there is an anti-Australian backlash in Indonesia at the moment, in this period of considerable pain when Indonesian society is facing up to the reality of its recent past, I do not believe that this backlash will be sustained or highly damaging to Indonesian-Australian relations.

The reality is that Australia has been a good friend to Indonesia. It was Australia that argued for a better deal for Indonesia from the IMF during the recent Asian economic crisis. Australia is well positioned to continue to be a good friend to Indonesia. It would be obvious to all Indonesians that, contrary to some of the rhetoric that is around at the moment, Australia clearly has no colonial or territorial ambitions and no intention to dominate outside our existing borders. All we are doing is attempting to assist in setting right a great historical wrong which has occurred partly because of our previous inactivity.

I would like to conclude by paying tribute to a number of people, firstly, as the honourable member for Menzies has said, to the East Timorese people themselvesâmany of whom are refugees in Australia, many of whom live in my electorate, many of whom I have dealt with many times at demonstrations, meetings and gatherings over the past few years and going long into the distant past. For their enormous courage, their enormous endurance, their enormous strength and their enormous integrity they cannot be beaten. To look at what the East Timorese struggle has consisted of, and how these people have endured and have continued to fight, provides an extraordinary example of human strength for all of us.

I pay tribute, secondly, to the Australian armed forces, those people who are risking their lives in East Timor. My heart goes out to them. My undying and absolute commitment to the cause that they are part of is stated here today and has been stated many times before. They will restore Australia's honour in this very sorry episode of history, and I pray fervently that they do not suffer casualties and do not suffer the sorts of consequences that clearly they are putting themselves at risk of suffering.

I would like also to mention a few individuals. The shadow minister for foreign affairs, Laurie Brereton, deserves great commendation for having had the courage at the beginning of 1998âwell before the fall of the Suharto regime, well before it was even seen as possible that Suharto might fallâto break with the past, however difficult it was for him personally in many respects, and change Labor policy on East Timor. He has been absolutely vindicated by subsequent events.

I pay tribute to US Senator Tom Harkin, whom I had the pleasure of meeting only a couple of weeks ago in Des Moines, Iowa. I listened to him speak about East Timor, explaining to American citizens why he has been actively involved in this issue, going back as long as 1976, and why he feels passionately about it. I commend Senator Harkin's extremely moving speech to all Australian members of parliament, for them to take some note of it. There have been plenty of people around the world committed to this issue, as well as many of us in this House and elsewhere in Australia.

Finally, I pay tribute to a person whom I consider to be a true Australian hero, somebody whom very few people in this House would have heard of, somebody who I think is representative of the groups of people who for many years have contributed in Australia to fighting this battle for East Timorese self-determination. I refer to John Sinnott, who is the key person in the Australia East Timor Association and who has kept alive this battle, going back as far as 1975 when he was involved with a number of others in setting up the Campaign for an Independent East Timor. He has worked tirelessly since then.

He has been in Melbourne for many years. He worked part-time as a teacher for a while, while working de facto full-time on the East Timor campaign. In more recent years he has taken a package from his job as a teacher to work full-time, without pay, for a number of years on the Australia East Timor Association campaign for an independent East Timor. You would have seen him, I have seen him, at every demonstration, every activity, every gathering. He is always there, unassuming, in the background, just working, not seeking glory. He was embarrassed at the suggestion that I was even going to mention his name in parliament.

While we are honouring the Australians who are risking their lives in East Timor at the moment, we should also recall those in this country who, like John Sinnott, have dedicated their lives to pursuing the cause of justice for the East Timorese people. When I see some of the rather doubtful individuals who get Australian honours, I think of people like John Sinnott, people who selflessly commit themselves to a genuine, very important humanitarian cause like the cause of East Timor.

As a longstanding Australia East Timor Association member, I say here today that I am very proud of John Sinnott. I am very proud of the many Australians like him who have played a very active role in this campaign. I hope that when East Timor honours its heroes, once it is established as an independent nation and the country is rebuilt, it finds space also to mention people like John Sinnott who have played such an important grassroots role in ensuring a decent outcome for a long-suffering people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âNo Australian could fail to be deeply troubled by the suffering of the East Timorese people over a long period of time, but especially in recent weeks. Australia's commitment to assist the people of East Timor in the terms of the motion before us was both right and necessary. Equally right was the courageous and determined role Australia has played in recent months in providing the greatest financial and logistic support to UNAMET, in providing the largest civilian police force to oversee the ballot, in its pivotal role in the evacuation from Dili of 1,800 UNAMET staff and East Timorese civilians, in organising and delivering humanitarian aid, in pressing for agreement from President Habibie for a UN peacekeeping force and in galvanising international support for such a force.

speech.para: We have an undoubted moral obligation to support the people of East Timor, to support their courageous stand for justice and to help end the 25 years of suffering which have seen over 200,000âa quarter of the country's populationâdie from violence, disease or starvation since 1975. For too long over those 24 years, successive Australian governments accepted the Indonesian annexation of East Timor. This acquiescence is even more inexcusable given the sacrificial assistance which cost the East Timorese over 40,000 lives in supporting Australians against the Japanese in World War II. It has taken this government to finally support the East Timorese stand for independence.

Australia has done what had to be done. Australia has done what was right. We needed to stand against the brutality, against the appalling atrocities, against the inexcusable bloodshed which we have witnessed in recent times. To have turned a blind eye again would have been unthinkable. Australia and the world needed to make it clear that such brutality cannot, and will not, be tolerated.

The 30 August plebiscite should have removed any hesitation the international community had. In the face of extreme intimidation, almost 99 per cent of the 450,000 registered voters turned out to cast their vote. Over 78 per cent gave a clear message of support for independenceâindependence come what may. The tripartite agreement of 5 May between Portugal, Indonesia and the United Nations confirmed the international community's obligation to support the result of that referendum.

The newspapers at the time of the poll carried some quite moving stories of ordinary East Timorese people who, in spite of that intimidation and in the face of the enormous risks, did turn out to vote. I would like to read two of those which I think really epitomise the nature, the determination and the courage of ordinary East Timorese people:

Brushing aside threats by pro-autonomy militia, Jubamal Salvador, 58, started walking at 4 a.m. yesterday to make sure he could cast his historic ballot on East Timor's political future. Clutching his registration paper, the slight villager, in a worn, checked sarong, was among the first of thousands in line when United Nations electoral officials opened the doors to the sports hall in south-west Maliana. Despite enduring months of militia terror and intimidation in a district with the worst reputation for political violence in East Timor, Jubamal said he had stuck to his choice. "We have been thinking deep in our hearts," he said.
The other story was the story of a young widow, Florentina Dos Santos:

Florentina Dos Santos is too young to be a widow, and her marriage to Vigilio Da Costa was too short. They had wed just two days before he fell to the ground, shot by an Indonesian policeman in the chaos that gripped Dili last Thursday. Yesterday, dressed in a black skirt and clutching a framed photograph of her handsome young husband, she went to a polling station just a few hundred metres from where he died and she voted the way Vigilio would have hoped. With tears streaming down her cheeks she said, "I feel obliged today to vote for what we have been fighting for, which is our freedom."
The tragedy is that since that ballot, the violence has escalated. Perhaps as many as 200,000 to 300,000 people have been displaced and perhaps 10,000 to 20,000 killed.

Australia has done all it can to bring this bloodshed and brutality to an end. Australia's military commitment to East Timor represents our largest military operation in 30 years. This is an indication of the seriousness of our commitment to the East Timorese, of the gravity of the situation there and of Australia's leadership in restoring peace and stability. Australia's military commitment will involve some 4,500 personnel. I would like personally to take this opportunity to commend the members of the Australian defence forces for their professionalism, their preparedness and their commitment to a cause for which it is worth taking risks. These are qualities which have marked Australian defence forces throughout this century, qualities which have brought immense pride to Australia.

Only the families of those departing can really understand the anguish of seeing their loved ones leave for action overseas. One of the weekend papers carried the story of a young woman who had just farewelled her husband. She was quoted as saying, `In spite of the risks, he is proud to be doing something worth while'. We are all proud of our ADF personnel, who are doing something which is undoubtedly worth while, something which is so obviously worth while, to bring an end to the suffering of these innocent people and to support their courageous struggle for freedom.

I would like to make special mention of personnel from the Richmond RAAF base in my electorate, many of whom are now in Darwin and Dili as air crew and ground support crew, as part of 36 and 37 Squadron of the airlift group. For them, and for all Australians involved in this cause, I want to assure them that the thoughts and prayers of our community and of our country are with them. We are proud of them and are behind them all the way.

I would like to make two other points. Firstly, I must record my disgust at Labor's hypocritical politicisation of this matter. Given their appalling record of neglect and denial towards East Timor, to be trying to score cheap points based on a totally dishonest appraisal of what, according to them, we ought to have done, is just shameful. I make no further comment on that.

I would like to close by making some observations regarding what lies ahead. Firstly, there will clearly be a need for considerable and long-term humanitarian aid for East Timor. There is widespread poverty in the country, GDP is less than $200 a year per head, adult literacy standards are less than 65 per cent, malaria and TB are endemic and infant mortality rates are amongst the highest in the world. In addition to this, recent events have destroyed much of the country's infrastructure. Australia announced yesterday an additional $4 million in aid to be administered through the Red Cross and other NGOs and much more will be needed in coming years. Our commitment will be long term and vital. Secondly, given the instability in the region, Australia's defence capabilities will need to be boosted. This is going to require significant increases in defence spending, yet I sense in the Australian community an acknowledgment and support for the need for this.

Thirdly, Australia remains committed to a strong ongoing relationship with Indonesia and will, I am confident, continue to assist and support the Indonesian people. Australia has provided much economic support to Indonesia in the past and remains committed to being a good neighbour. It is clearly in the interests of Australia and all within the region that Indonesia remains strong and stable. While recent events have created understandable and unavoidable tensions, it is important that we work to rebuild the bridges once the current crisis is resolved.

The struggle of the East Timorese people over such a long period of time has been a tortuous and bloodstained one. The journey ahead will be far from easy. However, it is hoped that with the support of the international community and certainly the support of Australia, it will lead towards peace, stability and security for the people of East Timor.

talk.start.para: âI certainly share the views of the member for Macquarie that Australia's task is not complete. The good news that thus far the Australian troops, who have landed on the ground, have not yet come in harm's way is to be welcomed and one would hope that that continues. But, even if that is so and the best case scenario evolves, which we can yet be uncertain of, the task of physical reconstruction, and psychological and social reconstruction of a people ravaged by the terror of the past few weeks, can only be lightly imagined. It can hardly be understood.

speech.para: I might say that only a handful of members have matched the rhetoric of their current participation in this debate with their actions in the past. There has been a longstanding organisation in this parliament called Parliamentarians for East Timor which always struggled for membership. I was inducted into Parliamentarians for East TimorâI want to make a bipartisan point hereâby my predecessor Michael Hodgman who took a strong and leading role in the establishment of Parliamentarians for East Timor. He has continued to act as an advocate and an activist for the interests of the people of East Timor.

Since my entry into this parliament some 12 years ago, I have belonged to that group and, I suppose, to some extent because of that, I suffer less from the sense of disillusionment that some in this debate are expressing. I think it was to be entirely expected that there would be some violent reaction from those who have, since the Indonesian invasion of East Timor, been complicit with the Indonesian regime. It is hardly likely that those persons were going to move aside without contest, and we knew that they were well armed and that they were working in conjunction with the armed forces of Indonesia.

I have had particular responsibility in the opposition for the Australian Federal Police since the last election and, whilst it is now our troops who are in harm's way, prior to the contingent leaving, it was our Australian Federal Police who stood on the front line, unarmed and in harm's way. I think it is important to record how significantly valuable has been the service of the Australian Federal Police, not just in East Timor but also the contingents that have served in Cambodia, Haiti and a range of other locations, and which have continued to serve, for example, in Cyprus in circumstances where they face the possibility of physical threat, harm and loss of life. That is rarely noticed, at least to the same degree as it is with others who are presently going in an armed capacity to stand between the militia and the people of East Timor who are trying to remake their lives.

It would have been so much better if this Australian government, when it was making the commitment to send unarmed Australian Federal Police to assist in the balloting process, had also engaged in a serious commitment to pressing the Indonesian authorities and engaging the United States and the international community to say, `These people should not be going in unarmed in harm's way without the backup capacity of a peacekeeping force.' It has not happened before. This is the first occasion on which the United Nations has supervised a ballot of this nature without the capacity of a peacekeeping force coming to assist.

I think it is a blessing that none of the Australian Federal Police who were there in those circumstances have come out, as best I understand it, with anything other than psychological disturbances. They must be psychologically disturbed by what they have seen. Some have been subjected to being shot at and stoned. They have witnessed people being killed and have been impotent to do anything other than to stand by, trying to separate those attacking from those being attacked in circumstances where they were unable to call on the sort of support that you would expect in those circumstances.

I understand that the Prime Minister defends his position by saying, `We did raise this with the Indonesians once and they rejected it, and I had lunch with the President of the United States, during which I discussed the security situation in East Timor.' I do not think that is adequate. I think it is wrong to focus too much on the past, but there are issues in the past and the way we dealt with this which need to be addressed. For example, in the parliament on 2 September, the Attorney-General, representing Senator Vanstone, was asked about pay and conditions for the Federal Police. It was revealed in that answer that even on that date the security assessment that was being enacted by the government was one which assessed the risk in East Timor as being in either the low or moderate band, rather than the high band. So the AFP personnel, who were manifestly subject to violence, intimidation, threats and watching this terror occur, were still then, as late as 2 September, being paid on an official security assessmentâthis government's official security assessmentâthat the risk in East Timor was not high. That is extraordinary, given all the advice the government was receiving.

There is one other person who comes through this debate with signal honourâthat is, the shadow minister for foreign affairs who, at some risk to his reputation, dissociated the Australian Labor Party from some of the positions that it had previously held. He accepted the legitimacy of criticism directed against his own party in respect of some of the previous actions that we had taken, but laid it plainly on the line that there was now a changed circumstance which required a different response, and said that the risk of terror, violence and massacre after a ballot was extraordinarily high. On his behalf, as he left to attend the balloting process, I delivered a speech to the Australian Institute of Foreign Affairs in which each of these matters and the warnings he had set out were specified. This is not a matter of making criticism after an event; it is identifying a criticism that was made by our foreign affairs spokesperson consistently and directed towards the government. And the government failed to react.

I know that the government, once its attention was focused on the magnitude of the disaster, did respond in a different way. I pay all commendation to the Prime Minister for the actions he took in New Zealand and the way he engaged the attention of the international community and then worked with the Indonesians to secure their assent. But would it not have been far preferable for that effort, where we could have engaged the interests of our allies and others, to be put in before that tragedy, so that our troops did not leave to attend a scene of massacre, a bloodbath or, in the language that people talk about, `supporting the courageous people of East Timor'? The courageous people of East Timor have lived with the circumstance of Indonesian invasion for 25 years. They do not need those words. They have lived with that. They needed a government that was attentive to the fact that they might face a massacre, and which acted to anticipate that and to minimise it. And they did not get that from Australia.

Finally, I do not wish to end on a critical note, but I should say that there was a very poor practice in terms of briefing the opposition. When it was first announced that an AFP contingent should be sent, I sought a briefing in relation to the terms of engagement and a whole range of issues that had logically come up: how are they going to be paid? What is their security? There were all those sorts of issues. Weeks passed during which we were fobbed off. That is not acceptable. When the crisis emerged, when it was plain that people were dying in their scores and in their thousands and when there were questions about the contingent, I again sought a briefing. I have not had the courtesy of a formal reply. Fortunately, I had informal advice from those within the Australian Federal Police, as you would anticipate. But I think that the government has botched some issues. I wish well those now standing in harm's way and I recognise the contribution that all are making in this cause. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to acknowledge the bipartisan elements in the remarks of the member for Denison and to state that I do not rise with any sense of righteousness or triumphalism. I am not animated by any spark of partisan feeling. Like all members of the House, I deplore and am frankly sickened by the humanitarian tragedy which we have seen unfold over the past three weeks, 730 kilometres north of Darwin. I am proud of Australia's troops, but it is not my principal purpose today to honour their efforts. That has been ably done by former speakers. I readily and sincerely defend the performance of the government, particularly the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Defence, in their efforts to build an international will to defend the East Timorese.

speech.para: My principal purpose in rising today is to respond to two recent acts of protestâone in Jakarta; the other in my electorate of Parramatta. The first was from an apparently distraught Indonesian woman, who is reported to have joined nationalist protests outside the Australian embassy in Jakarta shoutingâaccording to yesterday's Daily Telegraphâ`All I feel is shame. Why has Australia done this to us?' The woman was, I believe, a patriotic Indonesian, mystified by Australian activism in mobilising international sentiment. The second protest took place outside my electorate office in Parramatta and involved the splashing of red paint on the footpath of Church Street and the smearing of red hand prints on the doors of my office to signify the blood on my hands and, as the protest organisers said `the hands of all Australian politicians who have made this genocide possible'.

So what do I say to the woman outside the Australian embassy in Jakarta and to the protesters gathered outside my office, all of whom were condemning the Australian government? I suspect that we in Australia see Indonesia through an Australian prism, which is very different from the prism through which the Indonesians see their own country and indeed see Australia. To the woman outside the embassy, I would simply note that the East Timorese are Australia's nearest northern neighbours. We do not entertain a messianic view of our ability to solve the world's problems, and we prefer to exercise restraint in meddling in the problems of others, not least because we have plenty of difficulties about which to be humble on our own shores. It is likewise, however, impossible for us to stand by and do nothing when there is any instrument in our power capable of alleviating the great human distress, loss of life, lawlessness and displacement of tens and probably hundreds of thousands of people, the details of which have been beamed into Australian living rooms over the past two weeks.

Because of our proximity, Darwin is already acting as host to 1,500 East Timorese refugees. While we happily and readily provide that humanitarian supportâas we have to the Kosovars and, indeed, as we would to othersâAustralia has a direct interest in a peaceful resolution to the problems of East Timor. I feel, to some extent, a resonance with the famous remarks of John Donneâthat, when we see that suffering, we do not ask for whom the bell tolls, because no man is an island in spite of the geography of our two respective nations.

To those gathered outside my office, I would simply note that, since this government was elected in 1996, it has been an imperfect governmentâand perhaps imperfect in relation to East Timorâbut I would nonetheless maintain that we have taken the most activist role on Timor of any government since the abandonment of the East Timorese by the Portuguese in 1975.

The Australian prism, through which we have viewed the problems up there, involves a range of different refractions. For example, Australia has a population of 19 million people on an island so vast that it is described as a continent. Indonesia has 211 million people on over 17,000 different islands, atolls and reefs. From the southern tip of Tasmania to the Gulf of Carpentaria, the English language is a unifying force of communication; often you cannot even tell from their accent which region an Australian comes from. By contrast, over 530 different languages and dialects are spoken across Indonesia, which, aside from the practical difficulties of communications and governance, give some insight into the inhospitable terrain and the diversity of the regions.

In East Timor alone there are 12 different ethnic groups each speaking its own language. By contrast, while modern Australia had its national institutions developed on the back of an overwhelmingly European, Christian culture, Indonesia has always had to contend with a multiplicity of faiths and ethnic backgrounds. The result of that is that Australia's territorial integrity is a settled certainty with 100 years of peaceful continuity. Our colonial experience has been so good, if you like, that we are now trying to decide whether or not, as an act of volition, we will walk away from our links with England. By contrast, the experience of the Indonesians, with both the Dutch and the Portuguese, has not been so congenial.

I accept that in the mind of the leadership in Jakarta, both civilian and military, East Timor is seen as part of the question of Indonesia itself. There is a genuine and real possibility that the Indonesians will not be able to hold together the 211 million people, the 530 languages and the 17,000 different islands. I do not underestimate the very great challenges facing the Indonesian leadership. I understand the subtext which East Timor presents to them. In that context I salute the recent leadership of President Habibie both in agreeing to the poll in the first place, and more recently in urging the acceptance of its outcome by the Indonesian people. I understand that in doing so he is probably compromising, perhaps terminally, his own political future for an outcome which I believe to be in the interests of the whole Indonesian nation.

As far as our own strategic interests are concerned, I note that Australia is defended by an army of 25,000. The Indonesian army constitutes 260,000. Australians sometimes do not fully appreciate the geographical proximity of our two countries. The Australian adventurer Peter Tressider has paddled a sea kayak from Darwin to Timor and back again without stopping.

As every government's first sacred duty is the defence of its own citizens, I understand the sense of stewardship which previous Australian governments have felt about the relationship with Indonesia. Nonetheless, I join other members in being critical of the extent to which that relationship was based on fear and the inferior policy outcomes which that produced. Our change of policy, our current direction, does involve an act of faith. We hope that history will vindicate the act of faith which this government is taking.

We must be mindful that the lessons of history are bitter. When the Portuguese left East Timor in 1975, 200,000 East Timorese were killed in the civil war which followed. That is almost exactly double the number of war casualties that Australia has suffered in the past century. Therefore, we politicians need to exercise a certain restraint in the warm inner glow which comes from speeches about autonomy, democracy and independence when the consequences for human life can be so catastrophic. At the same time we walk that fine line of defending and acknowledging the universal principle that every human life has a sacred right to defence.

This government, with the support of the opposition, seeks to uphold that principle as we engage now in a peacekeeping force in East Timor. It is my hope that in defending the East Timorese we can avoid gratuitous insult to the Indonesians, and it is likewise my hope that the forces of civil government, of respect, of democracy, will gather force in unifying the Indonesians over the years ahead. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn speaking in support of the motion before the Main Committee today I want to indicate that, like all Australians, I have been appalled by the extraordinary violence we have witnessed in East Timor in recent times. As the member for Parramatta indicated, there is a history to all this, but this particular outbreak of violence has been particularly appalling and shocking to all Australians. Like all members of the House, I also support the deployment of the Australian-led peacekeeping operation and wish our troops well in the difficult task they have in front of them. Like almost all Australians, I look forward to an independent East Timor following the clearly expressed wishes of the East Timorese people.

speech.para: Other opposition speakers, particularly the Leader of the Opposition, have exposed in a very effective way the inadequacies of the way in which the government has conducted its policy with respect to East Timor in recent times.
