I do not wish to rehash those points. I want to focus my remarks very much on the future, especially on issues relating to the future relationship between Australia and Indonesia and between the Australian people and the Indonesian people.

Despite the horrific events of recent times, we need to continually focus on opportunities for taking forward the relationship between the Australian people and the Indonesian people. Peace, stability and prosperity, not only for Australia and Indonesia but for the whole region, including East Timor, depend considerably on the success we have in that relationship.

I am old enough to recall the early 1960sâI think I was just out of short pants at the timeâand I recall the attitude that existed in the Australian community in relation to Indonesia taking over what was then known as Dutch West New Guinea. I certainly recall as a teenager that by about 1964 Australian troops and Indonesian troops were shooting at each other in Kalimantan, so I do take with a grain of salt some of the claims that our relationship at the moment is at bedrock. I certainly remember the early 1960s, and I would suggest that the success in taking the relationship forward from those days gives us some cause for optimism about the potential to move in a careful and rational way into a productive future.

Australia does have vital interests in Indonesia. I understand our exports are running at about $1.7 billion annually. There are 300 Australian companies actively involved in Indonesia. Something in excess of $25 billion of Australian trade passes through Indonesian waters, particularly to North Asia. Despite the difficulties Indonesia is experiencing presently, Indonesia may well become the largest economy in our immediate part of the world over the next 20 years. We do have important people-to-people connections as well. I know that in my part of Melbourne there are very close relationships with both tertiary and secondary Indonesian students who are studying in the area. Those relationships are very important and productive on a people-to-people basis.

From a security point of view there are fundamental issues which are not just of an obviously military nature. The Australian National University's Strategic and Defence Studies Centre recently produced a monograph on transnational crime and illegal immigration in the Asia-Pacific region. I think focusing on those sorts of issues underlines how important it is for Australia's longer term interests that there be a satisfactory and cooperative relationship between Australia and our large neighbour to the north.

I think all Australians are aware of the devastation in our community caused by the narcotics trade. Close relationships to counter many aspects of that trade are obviously important in the way in which Australia controls the maritime environment and the maritime approaches to our country. It is desirable that Australia has effective and cooperative arrangements with Indonesia for that sort of task.

In recent times, illegal immigration has come very much into focus in the Australian thinking. This is a trade where, according to the document I have just referred to, some tens of thousands of people are involved internationally and where profits are upwards of $7 billion. Once again, the control of maritime approaches to Australia and the cooperation that Australia can achieve in those approaches are vital to our success in protecting our security.

Another area is piracy. South-East Asian waters are notoriously the worst in the world with respect to piracy. This represents a direct threat in many circumstances to Australian interests and Australian trade. So we do indeed have very powerful national interests which ought to focus us in the longer term. Despite our very powerful objections to so much of the way in which people associated with the Indonesian military have conducted themselvesâwe should not for one moment resile from those objectionsânonetheless we need to look at the broader context of the importance, over time, of retaining focus on the broad scope of the relationship.

We have an important interest in the democratic process and its development in Indonesia, as have the Timorese people. The very generous comments in today's press by Xanana Gusmao in relation to Indonesia, after all the events that have occurred, are very encouraging. The democratic development of Indonesia is most important from that point of view.

The history of Indonesia has not been one which has been characterised by democratic transition. The first two presidents of Indonesia came to power in the context of bloody upheavals: Sukarno in 1945, in the context of the revolution against the Dutch, in which Australia earned considerable prestige in Indonesia by our support for their anti-colonial struggle, and then Suharto as the second president, in the context of the events of 1965.

Suharto's departure from the political scene coincided with the end of three decades of economic growth and the economic catastrophe that struck Indonesia, with massive increases in unemployment and poverty, huge price increases, a falling through the floor of the Indonesian currency. I think Australia has developed some capacity for influence because of its response to that situation. The bipartisan support for Australian participation in the IMF rescue package, and the representations Australia made to the IMF and the United States to ameliorate some of the harsher aspects of the austerity program imposed on Indonesia by the IMF package, I think are matters that Australians of all political persuasions can take some pride and credit in. They form a basis for a sounder relationship in the future.

We all hope that Indonesia perhaps takes a path that is more comparable to that of the two other Asian countries that benefited from an IMF package, Thailand and Korea. The economic progress of those two countries appears to have recommenced, and that has clearly been associated with the process of political evolution and democratic development in those countries. Australia has a very powerful interest, as do the whole region and the Indonesian people themselves, in the process of democratic evolution. Australia can, I believe, play a useful and important role in supporting that process.

To conclude: the leader of the Islamic movement in Indonesia, Abdurrahman Wahid, has been quoted as saying, `Once you open the door, you can't shut it completely. That is the lesson. What happened to Nikita Khruschev after he opened the door by criticising the Communist Party? It accumulates during the Brezhnev era, after that with Gorbachev and then in the emergence of Boris Yeltsin. All those things show that, however little, sediments of democratic spirit will come through the filter and accumulate. So I do not think the next government will be able to reverse the situation.'

Let us hope that the next government in Indonesia does not want to reverse the process of democratic development. Both for Indonesia's interests in terms of economic progress, and certainly for Australia's and East Timor's interests, it is very important that we do go into the future in a region of peace, stability and prosperity. We as Australians, irrespective of our party politics, have got a vital interest in contributing to that.

talk.start.para: âAt a time when the fabric of our nation is being tested internationally, it is appropriate that all of us make a contribution to the national sentiment. In the cut and thrust of international politics and diplomacy, we at times become subsumed in the enormity and complexity of the issues. We are numbed in our sensitivity to the human dimension of government-to-government decisions, on the one hand, or international expediency, on the other.

speech.para: If there is one thing we should have learned this century it is that expediency is no substitute for principle. Whether that expediency is generated by appeasement or pandering to jingoistic national sentiment is not the point. The result is inevitably the same: a community or ethnic group is suppressed so that diplomats can rest easily in their beds and the world at large can delude itself that lasting peace has been achieved. It is a sad lesson of history that that is never so. There is no more potent an image of this than the picture of Neville Chamberlain waving over his head the piece of paper signed by Adolf Hitler and saying that he believed it meant `peace in our time'. It was the exact opposite.

Whether it was Hitler marching into the Rhineland or the occupation of the Sudetenland or the Anschluss with Austria in the 1930s, or the artificial imposition of the border between southern and northern Ireland, or the suppression of the Kurds who have never had a nation of their own for centuries, or the continued belief that Tibet is an integral part of China, we should all have learned that appeasement leads to no real peace and that salving the world's anxieties is paid for in human currency. It is no less so in Timor.

As Churchill succinctly put it: an appeaser is one who feeds the crocodile, hoping it will eat him last. Sadly, the crocodile is now right on our doorstep. And it is largely there because governments of both persuasions have opted for appeasement and expediency. The human currency in this instance has been the people of East Timor. One could hardly have envisaged a more horrific image than the ethnic cleansing and genocide that occurred in the land that is our second closest neighbour. Nothing can be more horrific than the sight of people being hacked to death with machetes, of whole communities on fire, of civilians being rounded up and marched along beaches to God only knows where, to an uncertain future, if not death. It has an eerie similarity to Poland just 60 years ago almost to the month.

We have all been forced now to take a step back and confront this horrific circumstance. Against that background, the government, indeed the nation, has contributed 4,500 troops, the largest movement of Australian forces since the Vietnam war. The fact that so many of our former allies and friendly nations have contributed significant troop numbers and logistic support to this action, and notably over such a short period of time, is a tribute to the negotiations and diplomacy of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. No international force of this size has ever been assembled in such a short time span.

I am appalled that the opposition has used this circumstance to endeavour to point score off the government. I am appalled that in supporting the resolution the subject of today's debate and then, while the eyes of the world are watching this debate and its implications, when other nations are probing our determination and the efficacy of our actions and assessing what our real sense of unity is or is not, the Leader of the Opposition should use his speech to chastise the government for some fictional deficiencies in diplomacy. This, I remind you, is from the leader who was a senior minister in the previous government, the government of Paul Keating, who showed the depth of his feeling for the people of East Timor with his dismissive outburst that he was not going to hock Australia's Indonesia relationship on East Timor.

What an appalling indictmentâto come into this parliament with this two bob each way attitude on such a seminal issue for our nation while you are up to those sorts of tricks yourself. Furthermore, to say that the current Australian government has been deficient denies the facts. The process that we see today commenced late in 1998 when the Prime Minister took up the matter of a period of autonomy leading up to an act of self-determination in East Timor. He took that up with President Habibie. He recognised the problem of security. That is why he wanted the period of autonomy first. In the event, President Habibie thought otherwise and opted for the quick decision. That left Australia nowhere to move.

It should also be remembered that the conduct of the ballot arose out of a tripartite agreement between Portugal, Indonesia and the UNâAustralia was not a party to that agreement. There were no provisions for peacekeepers as Indonesia insisted that it would be responsible for all security. The Prime Minister raised this with President Habibie when they met in Bali in April. The President made it clear that he would not accept any peacekeepers.

Despite this, Australia was a principal player in persuading Indonesia to accept a civilian police contingent, of which we provided 20 per cent of the number. It is a simple fact of life that, despite the shadow foreign minister's exhortations, in the event of armed peacekeepers being insisted on, the act of self-determination simply would not have occurred. Nor do I believe that China or Russia would have allowed it to have occurred in the United Nations. What I am saying is that there is no substance for this attack on the government and I think it really, if anything, depletes the merit of the opposition's standing in this whole debate.

Indonesia has no cause to be cranky with Australia. Certainly they may be hurting at present but Australia has supported Indonesia from the very time it broke from its Dutch colonial rulers and as recently as the Asian crisis when we assisted them financially. Australia has been a good friend and, if friendship means anything, it should be able to weather this current circumstance. But one thing should be made very clearâand Indonesia should not forget thisâthe days of appeasement over human rights are finished and Australia will not tolerate it again.

There is a human dimension to this. Three young men are identified in my local daily papers todayâthey are Grant Polson and Wayne Williams from Bundaberg and Johnny Craig from Gladstone, which is also in the northern part of my electorate. As the Bundaberg News Mail observed, Wayne Williams's mother, Jean, has seen three generations of her family serve this country: her father in New Guinea in World War II, her brother Kevin in Vietnam, and now her son in East Timor. They are indicative of a lot of Australian families.
I would also like to quote a little from the editorial today in the Gladstone Observer which says:
Spare a thought for Johnny's family, the Craigs of Craig's Bakery.

Let us hope, as some respected commentators predict, that the security force's passage into East Timor passes without incident, not only because it comprises hundreds of Australian sons and daughters but because there are far more important things to be done than fighting militia.

Overall these men and women should be allowed to get on with the mammoth task of restoring peace and providing safe passage for the estimated 300,000 displaced East Timorese, the sooner those jobs are done and the sooner they are home with family and friends.
I presume he means `the sooner the better'. I pray that these young Australians who hold the proud tradition of our country in their hands are protected by God and come back safely to this country.

talk.start.para: âWith Australian forces now on the ground in East Timor, we firstly wish them well and pray for their safe return. When governments commit armed forces, whether to the battlefield in defence of their country, or to the role of peacekeepers in a country suffering internal conflict, governments take on a grave responsibility. It is not something to be done lightly. Only when the defence of our nation is at stake, when required under our treaty obligations, or as is now the case, when human suffering results from the collapse of civil order in a neighbouring country, should governments place Australian lives at risk.

speech.para: Now at the request of the United Nations, Australia will lead a peacekeeping force in East Timor. This is a role that Australian personnel have some experience in. I am sure this experience will enable them to perform their task in a professional manner.

The role of the peacekeeping force is a difficult one. It lacks the glory of combat and, instead, offers the prospect of a long and, at times, frustrating campaign. It is a role which many Australians do not appear to understand. For the many who have called for our personnel to kick butt over there, there is a real concern that the Australian force, as the leader of UN forces, will face a diplomatic as well as real life minefield. Our leadership of the UN force will be a test of our military leaders and the front line personnel in the field. It is no place for Rambos, but for well disciplined professionals with a clear understanding of their difficult role.

The operation in East Timor will not be a short one. We may be committing our forces for many yearsâsome would predict for up to a generation from nowâalthough the level of our involvement may decrease in time. We must consider the impact of such a campaign on our defence personnel. Looking well into the future, there may be no victory parades for those who serve there although the risks are just as real as in a full combat role. For all those personnel, now and in the future, who will serve in East Timor, they must know that they have the full support of the Australian people. They must know that their sacrifice will be seen to be important now and in the future. It is all very well to be waving flags and cheering as service personnel depart for East Timor; we also need to be here when they return.

While we hope and pray that our personnel do not suffer any casualties, we should not underestimate the risks faced. We should be prepared to offer the highest standard of repatriation to those personnel who serve in East Timor and, in particular, give due recognition to their service. We must not repeat the mistakes of the past when dealing with Defence personnel who have suffered as a result of their service on behalf of the Australian people. I would expect this government to make an up-front commitment to ensure all who will serve in East Timor that they will not be forgotten when they return.

As I have said, we can expect our commitment to the East Timor peacekeeping force will be a long-term one. We cannot, as we have often said in the past, say that this will be all over by Christmas. It will not and, indeed, we may be looking at a decade or more of participation. Given the scale of Australia's involvement, this will be an expensive commitment. Already the government has indicated that additional resources will need to be provided to our armed forces in this budget year. Already the government has indicated that the money will be obtained by cutting into existing government services. This is not on. This government has already cut the level of services to the bone. Any further cuts could result in the total collapse of many valuable programs. If the situation in East Timor is critical to our national security, as it is, and if it is necessary to avoid a humanitarian disaster, as it is, then it should be funded in the fairest wayâthrough our taxation system. The burden of our commitment to East Timor should not be carried by the less well-off in our society, as it would if it were funded through cuts to government spending for vital services.

Australian forces in East Timor, as part of the United Nations peacekeeping force, will face a humanitarian disaster. Their task will be not only to establish a peaceful environment, but also to rescue a population on the brink of starvation and to restore basic services to allow even the most basic living standards to exist. After the optimism of 30 August, when the people of East Timor recorded an overwhelming majority vote for independence, has come the nightmare of retribution by the militia.

Instead of hope for the future for a free East Timor has come death and destruction, far worse than anything seen during the grim 24 years of Indonesian occupation of East Timor. Instead of setting about building an independent and democratic country, tens of thousands of East Timorese have been driven from their homes, driven into the mountains, to West Timor, and to Australia. If East Timor is to become a viable independent nation it could not have had a worse beginning. The task for Australian peacekeepers in the short term will involve restoring basic services in East Timor. No doubt there will be a further role for Australian aid organisations to assist in the rebuilding of facilities to enable civilian government to be restored.

As we consider the future we can see an independent East Timor emerging. This may be a long process, but some would say it is inevitable. A newly independent nation on Australia's doorstep will create many challenges to ensure the economic development of East Timor which will underpin the stability of the region. It is in Australia's best interest to ensure that the population of East Timor is assisted to rapidly rebuild their homes, farms and businesses. This will require additional aid to that already provided by Australia. We cannot skimp on the cost of this aid. If we do not provide this assistance we can expect the long-term stability of the region to be placed at risk.

The humanitarian disaster in East Timor has led to 1,300 refugees being accommodated here so far. The conditions imposed on those refugees anticipates their speedy repatriation in a similar way to that arranged for refugees from Kosovo. We should be clear right from the start that the situation in East Timor may well turn out to be different to that in Kosovo. It may be many months before refugees are able to safely return to East Timor. Without a major aid program, many will have no homes to return to and there will be little in the way of basic services. The main difference, however, is that East Timor is one of our closest neighbours and Australia is already home to many East Timorese who have established permanent residency here.

If East Timor is to be rebuilt into a viable, independent, democratic country, it would be of great benefit for refugees from East Timor to be allowed longer stays in Australia. This would enable them to develop skills and to acquire the necessities to re-establish themselves in their former homes. If Australia is to enjoy good relations with East Timor, the close links already established between East Timorese living in Australia and their fellow countrymen will be crucial to our relationship. As part of our humanitarian program for East Timor we should give special status to East Timorese refugees to enable longer stays in Australia rather than shipping them back at the first opportunity.

The torture, displacement, murder and beatings we have witnessed in East Timor in recent weeks have brought to world attention the plight of the people of East Timor. These have not been isolated events. The history of Indonesian occupation of East Timor from the time of the takeover has been one of systematic abuses of human rights and frequent incidents of atrocities against the people of East Timor.

While we might reflect on the background of how this humanitarian crisis developed and question the judgment of previous governments, it is what we do here and now that matters. The actions of governments over the past 24 yearsâthe response of the Whitlam government to the Indonesian invasion in 1975, the de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor by the Fraser government in 1979âmay be regretted. However, they did occur in a different time and world situation. The world of 1999 is a different place to what it was in 1975 or 1979, or even during the 1980s or early 1990s. In the world today, East Timor can be seen to exist as an independent nation. Australia has accepted an obligation to ensure that East Timor becomes free and independent. Now at last, after a quarter of century of suffering and struggle, the people of East Timor can look forward with confidence to a free and peaceful future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to join with my colleagues, and, indeed, all Australians, in supporting the Prime Minister's motion on East Timor which was moved in the House yesterday. This is one of those rare occasions when there is very little debate in the House other than to agree that we need to do urgently what we can for East Timor. It is a shame, though, that in agreeing on the broad principles there is some point scoring in terms of politicising the issue. As we know, all Australians are most concerned that we assist East Timor in every way that we can. What has happened in the past was, at that point of time, regarded as being in the best interests, too.

speech.para: Australians are often labelled as apathetic, as treating our way of life and our freedoms, our democratic government, fairly casually. In reality, we are very different people. We have always responded to a call to protect the freedom of others, especially other nations who have found themselves to be pushed too far by greater forces. We were, of course, the first nation to assist in the Korean War, which took place in the 1950s, when the United Nations moved to help to defend the South Koreans. The South Koreans remember us as one of the first nations to respond to their call for assistance. In Vietnam, it was likewise the case. We responded to that call for help from a community who saw themselves as under threat.

So Australia is not casual when it comes to defending the freedoms of others. We are certainly not casual when it comes to dedicating the lives of our young men and women to protect those freedoms. We have always been, and we continue to be, a voluntary force. Australia right now is leading the contingent into East Timor. It is only right and proper that we do so, given that we have a very special relationship with this island community. They were the people who stood between us and the Japanese at a particularly difficult time during the Second World War. They are people who are so close to us, only several hundred kilometres north of Darwin. East Timorese people have sheltered in Australia over the years when they have been trying to bring about their independence.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 12.57 p.m. to 1.09 p.m.

talk.start.para: âThe images beamed back from East Timor have spoken loudly to us of the devastation and the destruction that has occurred throughout the country, in the city of Dili and the provinces. That has been heartbreaking, of course, for the East Timorese and it is been extraordinarily frustrating for Australia and, indeed, the international community.

speech.para: Of course, 78.5 per cent of the people of East Timor were courageous when they voted for independence at the ballot on 30 August. That was a courage that a lot of other communities perhaps could not understand, given that it was inevitable that their times ahead would be tough if they voted for independence. But there was this overwhelming majority in the face of a concerted campaign of hostility and threats by the pro-Indonesian militia. We need to acknowledge that courage on the part of the East Timorese community. It is the sort of courage that is a real lesson to us in the rest of the world where we often take our democracy for granted.

The international community has a duty and a responsibility to respond to the crisis in East Timor that was sparked, finally, by the autonomy vote. Of course, Australia, in particular, has a special duty of care given our historic ties with the country and our closeness. We have both a moral and a strategic interest in promoting peace and security in East Timor. The tireless efforts of our Prime Minister John Howard, our Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and our Defence Minister John Moore in bringing the crisis in East Timor into the international spotlight are a very great thing. Securing diverse international support for the peacekeeping force must be properly acknowledged as indeed one of the most important things that this country has been able to achieve in international affairs in the last few years. The efforts of these ministers and of our Prime Minister over recent weeks and months have been integral in ensuring the true situation in East Timor was squarely placed in the international arena. It has played an integral part in the establishment of a peacekeeping force that is now deployed in East Timor.

Our clear objectives in sending Australian troops as part of the international peacekeeping force are to ensure the UN process in East Timor moves back on track so that the will of the East Timorese people and the mandate of UNAMET is implemented. The main tasks of the international peacekeepers as authorised by the United Nations Security Council resolution No. 1264âthat was, of course, unanimously adoptedâare to restore peace and order in East Timor, protect and support UNAMET in carrying out its task and to facilitate humanitarian assistance operations. Australia is only one of 12 nations contributing to the INTERFET coalition of peacekeeping forces operating under the umbrella of the United Nations, but we are proud to be leading that coalition of peacekeeping forces.

Our Australian infantry and support troops, in particular, have been preparing for this day for months and, in some cases, for all of their professional lives. Likewise, their families, wives, mothers, fathers and children have been preparing for this time when the troops actually go into active peacekeeping or combat situations offshore. As a mother of an Army captain myself, I understand only too well the great concern but, at the same time, the pride that mothers feel as their sons go off to work in this environment as professional soldiers representing the great nation of Australia. Like so many other young Australians in generations before, our armed forces, we know, will deploy in a way that will make us all proud and will also be an example to other nations that we work with. The Australian peacekeepers, as they follow in the footsteps of many other Australians, will be combining with the Federal Police, military liaison officers, consular officials and United Nations workersâall of whom have done so much in East Timor since the establishment of the UNAMET team some weeks ago.

In recognition of the sacrifice of our forces and their families here at home, the Australian government has made sure that there are benefits appropriate and suitable for our ADF personnel serving as part of the INTERFET forces in East Timor. The troops will receive special allowances, compensation coverage under veterans entitlement to military compensation schemes, appropriate and additional leave, home loan assistance and special re-embarkation and reunion leave. As well, there will be the counselling and contact services support should individuals need that when they return from this period of working in East Timor.

In my electorate of Murray, where I have been the member since 1996, it is this issue that has brought the biggest response to my office in the way of faxes, phone calls, letters and personal representation as the men and women of Murray have come out in very strong supportâfirst of all in apprehension wondering what could happen, what Australia as a nation could do, and now in full support of what this government has managed to undertake in the international arena in support of East Timor.

I want to make sure that this government understands that the men and women of Murray, many of them veterans who have been engaged since the earliest timesâwe had Boer War contingents from the electorate of Murrayâfully support and wish our troops well as they try to do their bit to secure peace in East Timor.

Our own local paper the Shepparton News has carried feature stories about the contribution of our young men and women who have lived in the electorate who now serve in the peacekeeping forces. In particular, Private Tim Nathan of Echuca will be serving in the 3rd Royal Australian Regiment and his proud but worried parents, Sue and Malcolm Whiteford, have all of our concerns and support going with them. Private Carl Van Zeist of Shepparton of the 2nd Royal Australian Regiment and his mum, Julie Reed, likewise carry the support of our community for the contribution they make at this time.

Shepparton is also the place where we have Radio Australia. The antennae are transmitting to our troops, making sure they keep in touch with the rest of the Australian community, that they hear our messages of support and that they hear from their own families. It is important, too, that we acknowledge that Shepparton is playing that very particular role right now in making sure that the airwaves move across the country and are received loud and clear in East Timor.

This is a very important time for Australians. It is a time that makes us proud in one sense that we can contribute and support a country that is at risk, a country that historically has been there for us in our hour of need. All Australians want to wish our soldiers and our government well. We know that our soldiers will serve proudly and bravely and help to re-establish peace and stability in East Timor. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn addressing the issue of the tragedy of East Timor, I want to speak about symbols and realities. The realities are these: the shadow foreign affairs minister, time and time again, from early March of this year, implored the government to insist on a peacekeeping force in East Timor during the ballotânot weeks after the ballot, but during the ballot.

speech.para: The second reality is that the government said no. It refused to do that. In fact, I understand the government went so far as to send an official to the Portuguese to argue against a peacekeeping force. Why did the government ignore these repeated calls for an international peacekeeping force during the ballot? I fear that one part of the explanation is that the government is obsessed with trying to outmanoeuvre the opposition at all times. I hope that is not the explanation but I fear that it is. I fear that the very fact the shadow foreign affairs minister called for this led to a negative reaction, that the government said, `Because you say we should do this, we will not.'

I have evidence of this in the Prime Minister's treatment of the Aboriginal statement of regret rather than apology. He told his own party room that he was not actually changing his position, but that this was a rather good manoeuvre because he wasâto use his wordsâ`blind-siding Labor on the issue'.

The next reality is that slaughter followed the ballot in East Timor. What I would like to see happen now is a reappraisal, an assessment by the government of its handling of this issue. Instead of the speeches that were made yesterday extolling the virtues of the government's handling of the issueâsaying we handled it, in effect, in an excellent mannerâa reappraisal should be made. Mistakes were made and I know we must move on from that. But I do urge the government, at least internally, to have a look at the procedures that it adopted and the interpretations of the intelligence that it adopted and ascertain where mistakes and misjudgments were made. This is a big issue and a big tragedy in our region and we must learn from our mistakes, and the first stage of learning from a mistake is to acknowledge that one was made.

I wish the peacekeepers a safe mission and I wish them an early return. I think I am able to speak for both sides of the parliament when I say I want to express the gratitude of the parliament to the families of the peacekeepers who must be going through a time of great stress by not knowing precisely what is happening to their sons and daughters, nor the level of danger that they face. It must be an awful time for them. I believe it is important for us all to think about those families and to indicate that we are very, very grateful for their sacrifice.

They are the realities; now to the symbols. Australia has betrayed East Timor on four occasions. The cock has not crowed thriceâas in the Bible when Peter was told by Jesus that he would betray him before the cock crowed thrice the next morningâin this tragedy the cock has crowed four times. Those four occasions were: in 1942, when we left the shores of East Timor, and slaughter followed at the hands of the Japanese; in 1975, when effectively we turned a blind eye to the Indonesian invasion of East Timor and we allowed that to happen without even so much as expressing concern; in the late 1970s, when we extended de jure recognition of Indonesian annexation of East Timor; and most recently in this latest debacle of 1999 when we told the people of East Timor that they should come out and vote without the fear of violence. And what happened? Violence on a massive scale followed.

In terms of symbols we can today, as a parliament, withdraw Australia's de jure recognition of the annexation of East Timor forthwith. When the Prime Minister was asked about this a few days ago he said, `What good would it do? What is the practical benefit of this?' That is why I am here talking about symbols and realities. That action would be not a practicality so much as an important symbol.

I would like to tell a very quick story. On the weekend, two good friends of ours were married. When the groom was leaving the house the door was locked and in the first car was the person holding the house key, one of the groomsmen. The car sped off. But left in the house were the two wedding rings. The wedding rings were symbols of the love and respect with which those two people held each other. They were just symbols, Mr Deputy Speaker. The groom said to his brother-in-law, `Would you please kick down the door of the house?', which he did, for the symbols, to get the symbols. They got the symbols, they got married, and I am very happy to congratulate Grant and Lena Musgrove and wish them every happiness in the future.

But as a symbol of our affection and respect for the people of East Timor I would dearly love the government and the parliament to withdraw forthwith Australia's de jure recognition of the Indonesian annexation of East Timor. It is, after all, the least we can do.

talk.start.para: âI am obviously pleased to speak to this motion on East Timor. I would like to comment initially perhaps on public reaction to what has happened in East Timor. I think we all agree that quite clearly, from the very graphic pictures we have seen on television, it is an appalling circumstance. It is perhaps an interesting sidelight to the times in which we live that these days wars and atrocities are very much committed in the full glare of television and they are brought right into people's homes.

speech.para: I think there has been widespread community frustration at the time that it seems to take to get things done. And in spite of the fact that the government was able to get the United Nations to move, for the United Nations, extremely rapidly, we did have that period of time when it appeared that things were going unchecked. That certainly has been a frustration for the community.

We have been asked quite frequently why there was no peacekeeping force in advance. I do not intend to go into that in great detail other than to say that I think the Prime Minister has made it very clear that, to have tried to do that against the wishes of the Indonesians, would effectively have meant an invasion of that country and, with their superior numbers, we would have seen large numbers of Australian body bags coming back. That would not really have achieved what most of the community desired.

There is great confusion in the Australian community about who is in control in Jakarta and who is in control on the ground. I think that most of us now understand that President Habibie probably is not in control. There are question marks as to whether General Wiranto is in total control, because what has happened on the ground in East Timor is not what we were being told in Jakarta would happen. Clearly, there has been some dysfunction in terms of control. We are now committed, with a number of other countries, and we wish our troops well in the very important work that they are going to do.

What of the future? It seems to me that we need to think about what is going to happen in the future. We need to understand that the peacekeeping force must be multinational. It will take a long time. It means that, therefore, we will have commitment of our forces and commitment of very substantial dollars for a long time into the future. Because of the proximity of East Timor to this country and the long association with it, inevitably Australia must be heavily involved.

We also need to understand that what is going on there is going to have a very heavy impact on politics in Jakarta. They are about to elect a new government and a new president and, clearly, there is some positioning of different people there. There is some ducking and weaving; there is some shifting of responsibility; and local domestic politics is playing a heavy role in terms of Jakarta's reaction. Unfortunately, there may even have been some religious overtones in what has happened, given that East Timor is a heavily Catholic country and the rest of Indonesia is largely Muslim. We also have concerns about West Timorâthe refugees are thereâand whether that will be used as a potential base for terrorism against East Timor in the future. We have also heard about not only Timor but the flow-on into other regions of Indonesia such as Aceh.

To me, all of that poses the question: what have we learnt? What has come out of this whole exercise, not only for East Timor but for Australia, our foreign policy and the way we conduct ourselves? I think Paul Dibb summed it up fairly well with a comment he made a few days ago when he said:
We are now more alone than we have been probably at any time since the 1930's . . .

I think he is right. As a country we do feel very much more alone in the world than we have done for a long time. Apart from the fact that the security treaty with Indonesia was torn upâand there are different views about the value of that exercise, nevertheless the symbolism was importantâthroughout this whole process we have had to talk to a lot of countries, and we found that the world out there is probably not quite as many people in the Australian community thought it might be.

A number of other Asian states were frankly cautious about getting involved, but it is to their credit that they have done so. There was significant community disappointment with the apparent reticence of the United States to lend their moral support, if not their actual support, and that has been a concern in the community. The United States link is one in which this country has had confidence since the Second World War. We have been unswervingly giving them public and swift support whenever asked, but it seems that the rules of the game have changed. We are told that there is still a very valuable exchange of intelligence data, but unfortunately none of us in this place and most of the public are not privy to that.

Since the end of the Cold War, it seems to me, the US has started to question whether it should be the world's policeman. It is increasingly saying, `Someone else should take responsibility. Our resources are not unlimited. It is not an issue that directly affects our national interest.' Timor seems to have fallen into that category. So our relationship with the United States has changed and we can no longer blindly assume that it will support us in our part of the world, at least not to the extent that we had previously thought. It seems to me that that raises a whole range of issues. I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Proposed Magnesite Mining and Processing in Tasmania
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 323)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the former Tasmanian Liberal Government and the former member for Braddon provide him information about proposed magnesite mining and processing in Tasmania and related energy options for Bass Strait; if so, what information.

(2) Did he indicate to the former member for Braddon that (a) he would personally take an overview of the proposal and (b) Mr Bob Mansfield of the Government's special projects team would be asked to take a leading role in advancing the proposal.
(3) Is the proposed Crest Resources 51 billion magnesite project in Tasmania on the Government's special projects priority list; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The former Liberal state government and the former Member for Braddon both argued strongly for support of the project. I received information which was provided to the Commonwealth on the nature of the proposed investment and its importance to Tasmania.

(2) During the last federal election, the former Member for Braddon announced that the Major Projects Facilitator attached to my Office, Mr Bob Mansfield, would oversee the project and make sure there were no unnecessary delays or impediments in terms of satisfying Commonwealth government requirements. This announcement was cleared with my Office prior to release.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Transport and Regional Services: Payments to Other Organisations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 694)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 June 1999:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: How many Australian ex-servicemen who were Japanese prisoners of war were alive on 30 June 1999.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: 3,078. This figure is based on the number of Australian prisoners of war of the Japanese who are currently receiving disability, service pension, and /or associated medical treatment through the Department of Veterans' Affairs, plus the number of deaths in this group of veterans since 30 June 1999. subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Air Traffic Control Clearances
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 804)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: Further to question No. 2619 (Hansard , 24 June 1997, page 5365), has the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) conducted an ongoing study of compliance incidents since 24 June 1998 to determine if trends emerge as to why pilots sometimes fail to comply with air traffic control clearances at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; if not, why not; if so, what trends has BASI identified.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: No, the Bureau of Air Safety has not conducted a specific ongoing study of `failure to comply' incidents since 24 June 1998. However, routine analysis of the Bureau's occurrence database has not revealed any adverse trends in relation to `failure to comply' incidents generally and, more specifically, at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: Has the Government undertaken negotiations with banks with a view to banks removing or reducing the fees that they charge pensioners for accessing their pension payments; if not, will the Government commence negotiations.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Yes. Centrelink, Treasury and the Department of Family and Community Services have jointly held discussions with representatives of banks, building societies and credit unions about ways of improving the information provided to social security customers on:
. low cost banking products and options; and
. banking practices customers could adopt to reduce or avoid the impact of fees and charges.

The Government's view is that customers will be able to maximise the benefits of competition amongst financial institutions if they have accessible and understandable information on these matters. These discussions have been held in this context.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Commonwealth responsible for the construction of on and off ramps on national highways.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the damage being caused to the economic development of the Ingleburn industrial estate in south-west Sydney by the absence of on and off ramps to the F5 highway south of Brooks Road, Ingleburn.
(3) Is the Government taking action to construct the ramps referred to in part (2); if so (a) what action and (b) when will they be constructed.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Works that are eligible for possible Commonwealth funding include the provision of adequate access to and from the National Highway.
(2) The Government is aware of statements from local community interests that have drawn attention to the issue.

(3) The Government is currently funding a planning study expected to be completed within the next few months, which examines the need for, and feasibility of, additional ramps on the F5 between Casula and Campbelltown in Sydney's south-west.
Decisions on any further steps, including priority and timing of construction and possible shared funding arrangements will be considered when the study results are at hand.

subdebateinfo.title: People with Disability: Labour Market Assistance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 821)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) How many persons with disabilities have received labour market assistance since the Job Network commenced in May 1998, either through (a) the Job Network or (b) services within the Family and Community Services (FaCS) portfolio, including the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Services (CRS).

(2) How many persons on a Disability Support Pension (DSP) have received labour market assistance since the Job Network commenced in May 1998, either through (a) the Job Network or (b) services within the FaCS portfolio, including the CRS.
(3) How many persons identified in part (2) as being assisted through the Job Network were provided with (a) Flex 1, (b) Flex 2 or (c) Flex 3 assistance.

(4) How many persons on a DSP provided with assistance through (a) the Job Network or (b) services within the FaCS portfolio, including the CRS, have achieved some job outcome, either as (i) full-time or (ii) part-time employment.

(5) Are statistics kept on the numbers and percentage of persons who, having been granted DSP, subsequently move off it into employment, training or education; if not, why not; if so, what do the figures reveal.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Job Network is the responsibility of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. I have asked the Minister responsible to respond to your question.

(b) Data on Specialised Disability Open and Supported Employment is not available for May 1998 to June 1998. Data from July 1998 to end June 1999 will be available in late September 1999. 31,567 from 1 May 1998 to 20 August 1999 from CRS Australia.
(b) For Specialised Disability Open and Supported Employment see 1 (b) 8,812 from 1 May 1998 to 20 August 1999 from CRS Australia.
(b) For Specialised Disability Open and Supported Employment see 1 (b). 2,016 from 1 May 1998 to 20 August 1999 from CRS Australia.
(5) Yes. During 1998-99 around 10,855 DSP customers had their payment cancelled or suspended because they returned to work or their earnings precluded payment.

In addition many DSP customers who commenced work at reduced hours or a pay rate would still receive part-payment of DSP. In the financial year 1997-98, around 7.3% of DSP customers reported some earnings from employment. Customers undertaking training or educational programs, generally part-time, can continue to receive DSP.

asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1999:

question.para: How does the Australian Bureau of Statistics assess the price increases of (a) groceries and (b) house prices for the purpose of calculating the rise in the Consumer Price Index.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is designed to measure changes, over time, in the prices actually paid for a representative basket of goods and services, including food items and new housing.

Prices of food items and new housing are collected at least once per quarter in each capital city by experienced ABS field staff. For food items, prices are collected from a cross-section of retail outlets, and for new housing, prices (excluding land) are collected from builders of project homes.
Full details of the procedures followed can be found in the publication A Guide to the Consumer Price Index (ABS Catalogue No. 6440.0).
